Posts.Content: JulieH wrote: I have been going on the assumption that my bc is at stage 1, but have a question.  My "mass" contained areas of both IDC and DCIS with what was characterized as an "extensive intraductal component."  The IDC portion was 1.7 cm and the DCIS portion brought the size to almost 3cm.  There is no node involvement.  Would this be considered stage 1 (because the IDC is less than 2 cm) or stage 2 (because the total thing was more than 2 cm)?  I know we're most of us not doctors, but I was just wondering what you thought. I'll definitely ask my onc when I see him next week, but this is something that's on my mind today. Any input is definitely appreciated.  Thanks! "When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive - to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love." - Marcus Aurelius Chemo started 1/18/11. Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 04:14PM JulieH wrote: Well, I wrote a whole blurb, hit the wrong key, and lost it.  I hate it when that happens!   Glad to meet you, citykitty, but so sorry you're here!  I'll be doing the herceptin every third week for a year, too, so I guess we're both in it for the long haul.  From what I gather, though, once we get to that point, the worst is behind us.  My husband was on the monoclonal antibody Rituxan for his lymphoma and, other than taking a long time in the infusion chair, it wasn't difficult at all.  His (now my) oncologist said the Herceptin acts in much the same way. I think I'm getting used to this whole idea, now.  I was pretty unhappy to find I'd need a re-excision, but the RO really felt the 1mm margin around some of the original tumor just wasn't sufficient, and I suppose it's better to be safe than sorry.  I bought my first hat yesterday and got my hair cut in a "boy" cut, just trying to get myself prepared to lose it all.  I've had long hair for years, and felt it would be easier to ease into having none at all.  I've always loved hats, so now's my chance to wear them.    I've been following the December chemo group, and it looks like, on the A/C regimen, the hair starts to really come out around the 14th day. I know what you mean about this whole thing not being in my plans for the year!  But here it is, and I think I'm ready to deal with it.  Thank Heavens for the groups on this site -- they've been a wealth of information and I've always found the best way to deal with my fear is to learn as much as possible about something.  Hope you have a nice and relaxing Christmas!

Having spent over 24 hrs at LaGuardia airport at this moment, and seeing you're from MA, I highly recommend flying out of the NE at Christmastime . . . :-) lee7: Will you be joining us in this group, or have you joined up with the December group? Thanks for the info on the port/no port issue. I'm supposed to have my port placed on Thursday (provided I get out of NY on time), and the idea of it gives me the heebies, even though I also think it's the best idea. So all the positive info I can get on it is good. Kym61, Steph42, amyK, ScienceGirl and navywife7181: Welcome to the group -- sorry you're here, but so glad we're all in this together and can give eachother much needed support. Kym61: My surgeon had said the same thing about the 2 diff. quadrants when he sched me for the MRI. Turns out it wasn't an issue for me. Good luck (?) on the HER2 tests. From what I gather, it used to be considered bad to have HER2+, but with Herceptin they're apparently getting really good results. amyK: Sorry the healing has taken longer than expected for you. Hope you're feeling better really soon. I'll be doing the DD A/C, too, but just 4 rounds of the Taxol. I've been reading the DD thread and the posts from the ladies on the December group, and it sounds like they're getting through it, although it sounds like it can take it's toll not to have that third week. Anyhow, seems that a lot of ladies are getting the DD, so maybe it's becoming more common. My onc did say we'd have to see how well I tolerate the regimen. ScienceGirl: As drastic as it must be, I'll bet you're relieved you went with the BMX. So glad there was no node involvement for you to keep you at that stage 2 level. Oh yeah, I believe we're going to make it through; maybe not easily, but we'll see the other side of this and beat the beast. navywife7181 & Tundra: Being stuck at the airport is bad enough -- but I really hope the ultra-cold weather goes away for your sakes! (And for all of you in Northern climates!) My best to everyone.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 07:41AM JulieH wrote: Hi everyone!  Happy New Year's to you all, and here's wishing that the next New Year's brings all of us better news than this one has. I treated myself yesterday and ordered a bunch of cute bandanas from Traders International.  Had to have the one with hearts and bears on it for Valentine's -- I think the kids at my middle school will appreciate that one.  Now I want to find one with Hello Kitty . . .  My port is marginally less painful this morning, thankfully, and I was able to get some sleep last night, having found a comfortable combination of pillows to keep me from putting too much strain on the port on one side and the re-excision incision on the other.  Warrior Princess: I'm so glad you were able to get on your mom's insurance before your diagnosis -- that's at least one thing that worked out in your favor, for sure.  I'm so sorry the lumpectomies didn't work out.  I haven't been able to bring myself to look at my newest incision, and I'm hoping that this newest chunk being taken out still leaves me with a good result.  As for your treatment regimen, it sounds like what a lot of ladies are getting.  I'll bet that you're scheduled for Adriamycin/Cytoxan (A/C) x 4 and then 12 of one of the taxanes (Taxol or Taxotere).  That seems to be one of the most common combinations that I've seen.  For a very realistic picture of what to expect from chemo, I highly recommend reading the December 2010 chemo thread here at bc.org.  Happy (almost) birthday! Hope your recovery from surgery continues to go well. If any of you are into reading about all this (this is the librarian in me), I found a very informative book called Living Through Breast Cancer by Carolyn M. Kaelin (oncologist and BC survivor, herself).  Lots of good information about dealing with SEs, the many types of surgery we face, the different chemo regimens out there, changes that can occur with skin, hair, mouths, etc.  It's the kind of book you can browse easily, just looking at the info you're interested in, and leaving the overwhelming stuff for later. Anyhow, hope all of you have a great day, and that those of you who've had tx already are feeling good and realatively SE free.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 01:46PM JulieH wrote: Lee7: My onc is going to give me the neulasta shot the day after my tx.  He says he's treated a lot of teachers and the illness hasn't been a real problem.  I'm hoping this is the case for me!  I'd really like to work as much as possible -- that's my way of maintaining as much normalcy as I can. Here's some info I got from the book I'm reading, with the drugs and the percentage chance it will cause hair loss: Cytoxan - %depends on the combination; Adriamycin (Doxorubicin) - 100%; Docetaxel (Taxotere) - 78.5%; Paclitaxel (Taxol) - 87%; Combinations: AC - 100%; ACT -100%; CEF - 95.5%; CMF - 50%. (Source: Kaelin, Carolyn M. Living Through Breast Cancer. NY: McGraw Hill, 2005.) So, it seems, if you're not getting A, you have a better chance of not losing your hair.  The difference is kind of small, but at least it's something.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 03:39PM JulieH wrote: Welcome to JeanH! It will probably depend on how full your infusion center's schedule is.  Since had a re-excision (congrats to you on the 2mm+ margin!), I had to wait some time to start, but otherwise I think they could have started me earlier this month. Proud_Mom:  You're sounding good today -- hope that continues for you! Moe0279:  Good idea about dyeing your hair a crazy color.  I've been thinking about dyeing mine platinum blonde (a la Dennis Rodman, since mine is really short now) or bright red just before my 1st treatment.  That way, if I hate it, at least it'll all be gone in a couple of weeks.    You're right about keeping it silly -- although it's kind of hard to laugh most of the time . . . slcst12:  I was reading about wigs in the book I have and she said that wigs with real human hair or a mix of synthetic/real can run to the 1000s of dollars.  Pretty ugly, huh?  Especially if you really don't like how they look . . .  Find one you like, and then consider the price.  Some insurances will pay for a "cranial prosthetic" (I think that's the term I've seen).  Definitely something to look into. Congratulations, Blindsided, on your last tx!  I know you must be thrilled.    I had my onc appt. today and got the path report that says while they did find another focal point of DCIS further up the duct, the margin on the other side of that was 2.5 mm, so I'm hoping that will be sufficient to appease my radiation onc.  I see the surgeon tomorrow, and he should be letting me know for sure.  I also had my chemo teach today and was pleased to see that there was nothing new -- I've learned so much from all the people on this site and the discussion boards.  It's been a good education.  But now I'm in kind of a funk -- it's really getting close, and each step makes it that much more real.  It's been so irreal, but I know that the moment I'm in that infusion chair, I can't keep telling myself that this isn't really happening to me.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 05:28AM JulieH wrote: Annie:  Quick post this am -- our schools are on 3-hr delay.  So sorry you've felt crummy.  And, really, I don't think it's TMI to mention the diarrhea.  If you can't talk about it here, where can you?  We'll understand, for sure.  Be sure you stay on top of the nausea.  If you're feeling queasy this am, don't wait to take something.  It's a lot easier, apparently, to stay on top of it before it gets bad than to get rid of it, once it does.  The one thing we need to accept is that some of us are going to be wiped out by this, and some will tolerate it really well -- and those of us who are wiped can't feel guilty.  We need to allow ourselves to rest as much as we need and realize that, eventually, we will get better.  One thing:  everything I read says that, in addition to when/if you spike a fever, if you get the shaking chills you need to call the doctor's office.  Hope your temp comes up soon.  For the mouth, my chemo nurse gave me a recipe for a wash: 1 tbl of baking soda, 1-2 tsp of salt and one cup of warm water to rinse.  Another thing you could try that I've read on other boards is equal parts (prob. just a couple tsp each) of maalox and liquid Benadryl to swish in your mouth.  Hope you're feeling better. I'll check back with everyone tonight.  Guess I do need to get ready for school . . .  I know, ice and snow is definitely NOT what we expect in SC. Hope everyone has a comfortable day!

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 06:30AM JulieH wrote: I feel like I've gotten behind the last few days.  I just finished catching up on everyone's posts and have really appreciated reading what ya'll have said about having to cut back.  I AM so used to being able to do the things I want when I want -- sickness just hasn't slowed me down in the past, and I really hate to ask people for help -- that now I'm having to learn to be a new way, and it's just not easy for me.  Maybe this will be among the major lessons I will have learned when this is all over.  I'm considering asking my Relay co-chair to take the whole thing over . . .  Guess I'll see how the tx affect me this coming week. Betsy:  I sympathize with your job situation.  I had been, for some time, considering getting into public library work and our local system had recently lifted its hiring freeze and posted some positions which I had applied for.  Hadn't heard anything and assumed they'd been filled, and, about a week and a half after I got my dx, I got called for an interview which had been scheduled on the day of my lumpectomy . . .  One of the hardest things I've had to do since the dx is call them and tell them I didn't feel like a job change was something that I could really contemplate at this time.  I, too, knew that all the appts and time off etc. would harm a new job situation.  But, I can say that, as terribly disappointing as that was, I have found so much support and friendship from the people at my school that the d*#$% BC has at least made me appreciate the place I am more than I thought I could.  One of the teachers came to me yest. with a lovely silk scarf that she said she'd never found a use for and asked if I would like it.  And we had a "jeans day" at school to benefit Relay for Life and the financial sect'y asked if I would mind if the stickers she printed up to show folks had paid to wear jeans said "jeans for julie.," which touched me deeply.  Seriously, I have come to see what a great group of people I work with. Hang in there, ladies!  At least we know as tx start that there will be an end to it all eventually.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 03:00PM - edited Jan 15, 2011 03:04PM by JulieH Baf4292:  I got a prescription for cipro, but that's only supposed to be if I spike a fever.  My onc is planning the Neulasta for me.  I think your regimen is interesting, though - and probably a LOT less expensive than the Neulasta shots . . . Cat123:  How's the hair holding out?  Jane_UK: It is a shock to go from long to short hair.  I did that a month ago and, while I was really worried, I found that I really like my hair short after all.  We have a similar program to the one you described in the US called "Locks of Love."  I've known several girls and ladies who've donated.  Good luck with that 18-yr-old thing!  Sciencegirl:  I loved your son's comment about Hillary Clinton.  That was a riot! All:  Those of you who are taking the L-glutamine; where do you get it?  Is it available at health food stores?  I've looked on the vitamin shelves of drug stores and haven't seen it.  I'd be interested to give it a try if it might help keep mouth sores away. Anniemomofthree:  Cookies sound wonderful! Tammy:  glad your anti-nausea meds kicked in so quickly.  I guess it only takes one time, huh?  I'm gathering that setting an alarm to wake me up throughout the night or remind me during the day to take the meds is going to be a good idea.  I hate not getting uninterrupted sleep, but think I'd rather that than feeling like I'm going to be sick. AliT:  I like your idea of just going ahead and being the one to decide when your hair had to go.  I think, for me, that might be a good option.  I'd rather deal with it on my terms.  So glad you had a great day and that the nurses were so good to you.  Nurses can make all the difference in a doctor's office. MaryMeg:  I, too, have kind of lost heart for my work.  I know there's so much more that I could be doing, but so much of my psychic energy has gone to dealing with this disease that I know my work has suffered.  No worries about babbling - I really enjoy reading your posts! ck_moma:  Welcome!  Glad your first tx went as well as it did.  Will you be following up the AC with Taxol or Taxotere?  Better keep the wig out of your dog's reach - I can just imagine him eyeing it with interest.  LOL! Sylvia62:  Welcome to you, too!  So sorry what you thought you were in for got much worse.  I went through that originally, too.  Thought it was DCIS (only need rads) and post-lump found out it was IDC.  It's like getting a kick in the gut, isn't it?  They really try to be aggressive with what they call "triple negative" (HR-/PR- and HER2-) cancers because those don't respond to things like Tamoxifen or Herceptin.  We're going to be on almost the same sched - I just start on the 18th rather than the 19th.  I think a lot of us are just waiting to see if we can continue to work.  I'm hoping to be able to work as much as possible, but am prepared to take as many days off as I have to.  Thankfully, my principal is very supportive and understanding (at least he has been).  Good luck to you! I had lunch with a good friend today and came home and vacuumed and mopped the floors.  I think the cleaning made me feel better, which is a little weird because I really don't much like doing housework (which is actually an understatement).  DH said he'd be happy to do it, but I told him I really wanted to because I just don't know how much energy I'm going to have in a couple of weeks.  Anyhow, it felt good to be active, even if it was just mopping! T minus 62 hours and counting 'til tx.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 07:16AM JulieH wrote: Amara:  So sorry you're joining this club!  We have a couple of ladies doing the neo-adjuvant chemo to try to shrink the tumor before undergoing surgery.  From their reports, it's working just like it's supposed to.  You'll want to know what your course of treatment (tx) is going to be, will it be dose dense (every 2 weeks) or not (every 3 weeks).  If it's HER2+ (like mine), you'll probably get Herceptin for a year but some people will get it weekly (me) and some will get it every three weeks.  If you don't know yet, you'll want to know the size of the tumor, the grade (1 - 3) of the tumor, the type of cancer it is (Invasive Ductal Carcinoma - IDC; Invasive Lobular Carcinoma - ILD; Inflammatory Breast Cancer  - IBC  - just to name a few).  Like sciencegirl said, you'll want to know if its Estrogen/Progesterone Receptor (HR/PR) positive or negative and the degree.  Mine is ER+, but only 1%.  Some ladies' is ER+ or PR+ (or both) at 100%.  That will determine if you will be recommended to take Tamoxifen.  There's so much to learn, and the learning curve is so steep when you first learn that you have cancer.  This site is a wonderful resource, the mayo clinic's site is excellent, and the American Cancer Society's site is as well. Good luck!  And if any of us can help, don't hesitate to ask.  Feel free to PM if you like.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 04:45PM JulieH wrote: I feel normal, finally, today (except for some food issues, as in, not wanting to eat but feeling hungry). Just wish I had more than one week to feel like this.  ProudMom: I'm so sorry you were feeling so bad earlier. Of course you can vent -- and I share your love of the word "crappy" -- it just seems to fit so much of what is happening to us. And it is exhausting keeping up the good front -- which is part of the reason when folks at school asked how I was doing, with many of them I told them exactly how I was feeling. I guess I figure if they're going to ask, I'm going to be honest, and if they don't really want to know, they'll quit asking. Those who truly care will continue to ask. I'm glad you're looking into paring back. I love what MaryMeg and AimeeMac had to say about our main job is to heal. After all, that's why we're going through this "crappy" chemo for. Take time for yourself, do something YOU enjoy because you want to, and know that the outside world will take care of itself for awhile. I sympathize with your dislike of asking for help -- I have had a problem with that my whole life. Somehow we'll figure out how to ask, I guess. Let us know how you're feeling. We're here for you. Queenjazz: I know I've read on other discussion boards (probably the December or November board) that others were dealing with vision issues. I looked in my Living Through Breast Cancer book and there was no mention of vision problems. Also, no mention of such problems in the information sheets I got at the onc's office. But obviously there's something going on for so many to be experiencing it. UTMom: You are so right, it is way too soon. I've lost another couple of pounds and don't really feel like I'm eating any less than I was before. Everything I've read says we should eat what we feel like so if that ravioli and ice cream sounds good, I say, "go for it." My problem is almost nothing sounds good, although I did find that 5 Guys Burgers and Fries' french fries were really appetizing this weekend . . . bdavis: Good luck with the Neulasta. I'm taking off work the day after my shot next week because of how miserable I felt that day last tx, so I sympathize -- and I was taking the Claritin. I may have to move to something stronger than ibuprofen. It took me until today (day 8) to really get rid of all the pain, so I wouldn't be surprised if you were still feeling the pain yesterday.hsgray: How's the cough doing? Did you have to follow up on it? Hope you're feeling OK. lorenar: Welcome to our little community -- hope you're able to draw some strength from us here! How are you feeling today? Hope the nausea was minimal for you. Are you doing one of the taxanes or the AC to start with? Looks like you'll also be doing Herceptin like I will. Check back in and let us know how you're doing. MaryMeg: Nanaimo bars -- wow, I haven't heard anyone else talk about those since I left the Pacific NW 20 years ago, although I do have an Oregon cookbook that has a recipe for them. amelia2: Glad your rash is doing better! Did your doc think it was from the Taxol (Taxotere?) or the Herceptin? I've heard the Herceptin can have allegy-type reactions. Beckie: Yay!! You sound great, and already on your feet doing hair. I don't know how you do that when you're perfectly healthy (standing all day like that) and I think it's wonderful that you feel up to it now. Anniemomofthree: We can take all of the drugs at once? That could be useful when I'm trying to sleep off my SEs next Wednesday and Thursday! I'll be pulling for you to have many fewer than 12 days of bad SEs next round. How nice that your onc is working so hard to get your SEs under control. And good luck with the disability. I would seriously have considered it but I don't have short term disability insurance and I can't afford the leave without pay until long term would kick in at 90 days. Kym61: Good luck getting in to the office tomorrow. Seems like it has done nothing but snow in your neck of the woods since Christmas. Pumpkin roll sounds good (one of the few things that does!). jcoutee: Welcome to you, too! Glad you found us. Have you checked out the TN discussion board? They seem to be really active. (I originally thought I was going to be TN based on the needle biopsy -- that changed, though.) Looks like you and Moe are doing the same protocol (Taxol followed by AC). AimeeMac: Your husband's comment took my breath away. It is support like that that we all need. What an amazing thing. Truly. And good reminder from your friend. Sounds like you have a wonderful support system!

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 05:56PM JulieH wrote: Hey all!  I've been a no-show for the last few days, but I felt so crummy after the last tx I could hardly get up the energy to do much of anything.  I have kept up on everyone's postings, though.  I did want to say that while I felt more nausea, the neulasta pain did not last as long with this 2nd shot.  Of course, we know that each of us reacts differently, but at least that's one person's reaction . . . The only thing that's keeping me going is the knowledge that I'm half through this AC round.  I feel like such a baby, but I just can't stand feeling like this -- unable to do the things I'm used to, constantly feeling on the verge of wanting to throw up, etc., etc.  I went to the opthalmologist today because of my eye issues, and talked with him about the dry eyes I've been having.  He said to really watch them and if I find I'm having to use the lubricating drops more than 6 times per day that I need to go back and see him.  He says he sees a couple of patients per year on chemo whose eyes are in really bad shape because of how dry they get.  So don't let it get bad, ladies.  Kind of a downer, tonight.  Sorry.  Hope ya'll are feeling OK.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 10:46AM JulieH wrote: 3/4 AC day 7; 0/4 T; 0/52 Herc.; Start 1/18 Good to be back and check how everyone is doing.  I've been away for a couple of days -- just seems like I don't have the energy on days 4, 5, and now 6, to do much of anything.  I have developed a tremor in my feet/legs now, too, and was wondering if anyone else had developed anything like that?  I think it's probably from the compazine, which also gave me horrible jitters/agitation this time around.  Anyone else dealing with anything similar? For the constipation, my insurance nurse navigator said to take the colace regularly, not just on the days around the tx and it does seem to have halped this round.  The warm prune juice with a sliver of butter has always been recommended by my husband's and my onc nurses, too, if you want to avoid the chemical laxatives. Hang in there, everyone!

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2013 02:05PM JulieH wrote: Just checking in after several months away.  So terribly sorry, leftfootforward, that you are having to continue this crappy journey.  I sincerely hope that your treatments are effective, and that you continue to beat the sh*& out of the cancer.  All love and light to you in your battle, and wishes for strength and healing, and a circle of family and friends who will always support you. I am finally off the three month cycle and now will only have to see my onc every six months.  My DH is, for the moment, again in remission.  Lymphoma is a crapshoot -- one year you'll roll the dice and everything's ok, the next year, not so much.  So I take every year we get with joy, and hope the dice turn up right with the next scan . . . I still forget things all too easily, and get frustrated much more quickly than I did before the treatments.  I wonder if it will ever go away, or if this is just my new normal.  I suspect the latter, and I guess I just have to accept that with as much grace as possible. My best to all.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 03:41PM JulieH wrote: I have a book suggestion, but only if you're not offended by some pretty strong language. The title is Cancer on $5 a Day. It's written by a comic who has been a regular on Howard Stern's show, so you know he's pretty "salty," about his experience with Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Not a funny subject necessarily, but he was always able to find the humor in his situation and I found myself laughing out loud a number of times, notably in the infusion chair last week. I think the author's name is Schimmel but I'm not sure about that (I'm starting to forget a lot of things . . .) but you can look the book up on Amazon or Barnes & Noble. I went to the doc today about my eyes and he reiterated that dry eyes can be a problem and that my ongoing sinus problems contribute to this problem. He said I should start to use the natural tears eyedrops regularly. I'll see if that helps. My head has started itching a lot. I figure this is a precursor of things to come . . . Anyhow, I've planned to shave my head this weekend, so my scarves are ironed and ready to go. Tomorrow is a "caps for a cause" day at school (middle school kids pay $1.00 to be allowed to wear the hat of their choice), so I'm planning to debut a little red velvet hat I bought a month or so ago. They'll be seeing more of it in the weeks and months to come! SSIrish: So glad you decided to jump into the conversation --but certainly sorry you're here to begin with. Hope you're feeling well this third day of the cycle. Maybe the intestinal issues won't be quite as bad this time around. It's crummy to have had to go through chemo on your birthday! I'm with WebU, I loved your comment about Rhoda -- I used to watch that all the time when I was a girl. I always thought she looked pretty chic in her scarves! Emend is a great drug -- I was glad I'd had it for tx 1. I think I would have been much sicker without it. Glad you qualified for the ACT program -- it will make things a lot easier, for sure. Moe0279: Bad news about the neuropathy -- hopefully the feeling will come back for you once the txs are over. How are you feeling today? Hope the fatigue has eased up for you. Beckie: Sorry your 5th day wasn't as good as hoped -- has today been better? How did the wig shopping go? And I agree, BC sucks, big time! MaryMeg: Hope you're feeling OK today. My onc's office doesn't have wi-fi for it's patients (I don't think -- they haven't in the past when my DH was going for tx), so I sympathize with your frustration. I'll join the "pathetic club," MaryMeg. Thankfully it doesn't bother me -- it just lets me know they sympathize/empathize/are sorry I have to deal with this. What did bother today was when a co-worker told me today that he knew "exactly what I was going through" because his 1st wife many years ago spent a lot of months going through Hodgkin's treatment . . . I am sorry he had to deal with that, but he can not know exactly how I'm feeling until he's sat in that infusion chair himself . . . even then, he'll never have to worry about losing his breasts, and a bald man is much more accepted than a bald woman. Otherwise he's been very supportive of my situation. Hate to complain, but, really . . . AimeeMac: I love the NW -- grew up in Oregon and went to school at the U. of Puget Sound. I'm jealous of you getting to live in the Seattle area! (Even though I don't miss the many months of grayness . . .) I looked up my recipe for Nanaimo Bars and it's pretty much the same, but instead 1/4 C of butter it calls for 1/2 C. Pretty rich stuff! navywife: Happy birthday! Just wish you didn't have to spend it getting chem . . . Hope you're feeling better -- glad you didn't have to spend more time in the hosp! The Neulasta does cause pain, but, as with so much, some tolerate it better than others. I had quite a bit of pain and am not looking forward to it againg, but would rather that, I think, than spend time in the hospital. Lorenar: Hope you have been well today. Don't forget to take your advice and don't push too much, and be careful out in the snow! :-) My parents have a house in near Martinsburg, but they spend winters in Florida because they couldn't take the snow any more. ProudMom: Glad you're feeling better! Remember that steroids can really mess with our emotions, too. Take care, and vent if you need to! amelia2: If you are able to "go commando," let us know. I'm considering it, but don't know how knobby my head is going to be without hair. It would take guts not to have some sort of covering, and I don't know if I have that many. Good for your son! Have a lovely weekend. sciencegirl: Yes, why don't they let us sleep in on snow days? My district during the last snow "event" had the decencey to call school off the evening before, but they're not usually that considerate. Thank you for your thoughts about the future. Not only for those of you with children, but for all of us, as well. We are all young enough that advances in 10 or 15 years will have an impact for us, as well, should we ever have to deal with recurrence. And "keep smiling, or not" -- such an appropriate sentiment, because we do need to allow ourselves those days when smiling is just too much to contemplate. Thank you. webu: What a relief to be done with the mouth sores -- those are so painful anyway, I can only imagine the chemo induced ones are miserable. I'm actually looking forward to wearing my Gaila, too. They really are cute, and certainly not in my "usual' wardrobe!

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 10:59AM JulieH wrote: Just came back from my second AC a bit ago.  Uneventful, which is how I like it.  They are just doing my bloods the day of tx, no in-between draws.  My levels were good today -- the onc said just what he'd expect from a 44-year-old.  Wasn't much looking forward to today, knowing that I'm in for a few days of feeling crummy. I have to say I love reading what you all have to say -- both good and bad.  I hate that so many of us are having a hard time of it, but it feels good to know that none of us is alone -- we have each other for support and understanding, and that means so much. Thank you, Annie, for your milestones.  While we're not getting snow this time around in SC (be safe, y'all), it has been much colder for us than normal for longer than normal, and it's nice to think that spring really IS just around the corner.  Definitely something to look forward to. I have been sleeping in a cap that one of my mom's friends knitted for me.  It's knitted from a really soft, fuzzy yarn and doesn't have any elastic but just pulls down over my head, like a stocking cap.  Patterns are available on the web for "cancer hats" if you or someone you know knits, webu.  Also, the newer style fleece hats might be more comfortable than the cap you were trying to sleep with. I buzzed my hair to a 1 on the clipper guard, and I expect that will all come out in time, too.  TMI, maybe, but for those reading who are new to the whole experience you'll need to know, my pubic hair has really started coming out, so I figure the rest won't be too far behind.  I'm really not looking forward to my nose hair coming out -- I hear the runny nose that results is annoying.  And I'm stuffy all the time (I own two cats and am allergic . . .), so I need to get used to carrying tissue with me at all times so I'm not using my sleeves.  Anyhow, just more on the list of annoyances, big and small, that we get to deal with. Good luck with the SEs, everyone.  I think I'm off to nap the AC off . . . (if the decadron will let me).
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 03:27PM JulieH wrote: Welcome golfergrandma!  Sorry you're here, though.  Do I read you right, is this your second time doing chemo?  Doubly sorry for that, if so.  I don't know about the wine -- I like a glass from time to time (margaritas are even better), but have just assumed we needed to stay away from it.  Anyone else know? Webu:  I love your scarf.  Was that one of the freebies we can get? The colors are really nice. Question:  Has anyone else "seen stars?"  Just a bit ago I started seening the little flashy lights like you get when you bonk your head and I was just wondering if anyone else has had this or if this is unrelated to the chemo. Had my neulasta shot today -- no issues there.  I expect the pain to kick in tomorrow, but will be overjoyed if it doesn't. Stay safe, everyone.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 04:07PM JulieH wrote: anniemomofthree:  I think the tiredness is pretty common; one of the cumulative things I've heard of.  But, are you getting enough iron?  Anemia could make you tired, too.  Hope your energy level is up soon and stay warm! Beckie:  What a lovely picture -- you DO do bald beautifully.  The happiness in your eyes just shines through.  And, Go Pack!  WebU:  Glad you're feeling better now -- the nausea is just the worst, even when it's under control. I'm finally feeling like a real human today, except the tiredness and a sore throat I'm working on and hoping it doesn't get too much worse.  Had a student in the library today with an obvious bad cold just coughing right out without covering and I kind of got on him about it.  But also had a student tell me she was "so mad" when she found out what was happening to me.  So many of them have hearts of gold, it does my heart good. My positive for today just came on the TV--HBO is showing Castaway (which I love) and it's going to be the first time I've seen it uncut and commercial-free since the theater.  Anyone else have a movie they just can't resist watching any time it's on TV?

It's gotta be scary having to go in, but a good thing you caught it when you did. We saw a local production of "Cat" this last year -- they really tried to highlight the humor . . . We kind of said WTF to ourselves as we were leaving the theater. I've never seen the movie, but I'll bet it was way better than the play we saw! tfinn, 1Miclon & kadorazio: So glad you're with us and drawing strength from the amazing women here. I, too, have gotten so much from each and every one here. Looking forward to hearing more from you! 1Miclon: I am so sorry for the loss of your DH. And now this for you. Hang in there and lean on us as much as you need. We're here for you. kadorazio: Good luck with your tx tomorrow -- be sure to ask your onc for something stronger for the nausea. My onc has said there's no reason anyone needs to go through that kind of nausea/vomiting these days. There should be something else they can do for you. And I love your avatar -- is that from icanhascheezburger? sherryhutt: How nice for you to get the support from your daughter. And what a sweetie your DH is! My dad has shaved his head in support of my situation, too. I'm seriously considering going commando at school in the near future. My hat today was so hot, I kept having to go into the restroom to take it off for a few minutes. I've asked a number of teachers if they think the kids can deal w/ a bald me, and they said they think most will be able to, and those for who can't it can be a "teachable moment." Any ideas from y'all?

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 06:05AM JulieH wrote: Start 1/18; AC 2/4 day 13 T 0/4 H 0/52; next tx: 2/15 Emily:  Mouth problems are pretty common, I think.  Dry mouth can cause a lot of sensitivity problems.  My guess is your onc will have seen this before.  Can Biotene products help maybe? MaryMeg:  Good luck with the candy search! I'm feeling pretty good today, despite the ever growing list of SEs (heartburn, bad hemorrhoids, annoying eye problems, bald head, etc., etc., etc.).  At least I'm not queasy today.  My DH and I have reservations at a little Italian place for tomorrow for Valentine's and I'm so thankful I'm feeling good.  I know I won't be feeling so good next Saturday on my birthday, so I've told DH he's getting off easy this year, only having to pay for one special dinner this week!

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 06:06AM JulieH wrote: I had my second Taxol yesterday and go in this morning for my Neulasta.  Much as I hate the Neulasta pain, it seems to be doing the trick for me; my WBC has been staying right around 23.  Now I'm bracing myself for the pain from the Taxol (had it last time; pretty vicious . . .), but hoping it won't be so bad.  I agree, Proud_Mom, as I get closer to the end, the burden feels so much lighter.  My last tx will be on the week of the 26th, then on to rads, probably starting in May.  I have my appt. with the rad onc for my re-evaluation and CT scan the week of April 18th and then the "mark-up" on the 26th.  Despite all this time off from work, I'll still have about 30 days of sick leave left when all this is done.  I did ask my onc yesterday about the Tamoxifen and, even though I'm only 1% ER+, he said he'd recommend I at least try it.  If the SEs prove to be too crummy, he said it would be OK to stop, but he thinks I should give it a try.  (The idea that it can lead to uterine or ovarian cancer is pretty daunting . . .) I'm envious of all of you who've finished -- but so happy for you too.  Keep in touch and let us know how rads are going.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 08:31AM JulieH wrote: Congrats, MaryMeg, on finishing up!  It is amazing, isn't it, how quickly one's outlook improves once that last infusion is done.  Sorry to hear about the issues with your hand.  How quickly do they think that will clear up for you? UTMom:  Glad you're back on track -- hope nothing gets in the way of your next four tx.  My eyebows and eyelashes started to come out about the 2nd taxol tx and finished falling out after the last.  But, 7 weeks PFC my brows are about 1/3 of the way back and my lashes about the same.  Tammy:  I had 20/33 rads yesterday, and that was the first time I felt tired enough to need to take a nap; but it wasn't so bad that I couldn't have continued had I been at work.  My skin just started to get red this week, although I have had a lot of discomfort with my nipple since the first tx -- can't sleep on my stomach.  No bad skin issues yet.  I have been using a thin film of aquaphor daily since my second week and twice daily starting a week ago Wednesday.  My RO said to apply it right before bed to start and said if it hadn't absorbed by the morning, I was using too much.  It's an annoyance having to go every day, but that's really the worst so far. My hair, 7 weeks PFC, is about 1/3" long and I gave up my headcoverings a couple of weeks ago.  It feels so good, now, not to be wearing anything to cover up.  It felt strange and naked at first, but I finally just said WTH.  I have gotten "looks," but mostly from younger kids who are obviously curious.  No adult has given me anything resembling a "pitying" look.   My husband has even said it's going to be strange to see me with hair, since I've been walking around home since late January completely uncovered.  I will say, the hair on my crown is fairly dark, but I think the hair on the side of my head is coming in gray, and I'm not thrilled at that, being only 45, but I guess that's what hair coloring is made for.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2011 06:56AM JulieH wrote: Proud_Mom:  Sounds like you're working back into the work world well.  I, too, find myself forgetting things so I tell everyone if you need something from me, be sure to send an email because I'm likely to forget otherwise.  I also have to be very good about writing "to do" lists, or things just don't "get done." That said, it feels so good to be back up and running, so to speak.  I really get a sense now of how much I was coasting last spring, in comparison with what I feel up to now.  But I feel re-energized about work, now, too, and I know that that's also a result of just wanting to get by last year.   I, too, am seriously contemplating keepin my short hair-do.  It's so much easier.  So far, it hasn't really shown any sign of curling; but at about 1", it may still be too short to do that.  I have a LOT more gray now than I ever did, and while I've had a number of people compliment me on the color (?), I'm sure I'll be coloring it in the near future.  I've always looked a lot younger than my 45 years, and I'm not ready to start looking like I'm in my 50s. Physically, I'm doing OK.  My arms and hips still bother me -- my range of motion is limited -- and I think I may need some physical therapy.  It just seems to have settled in my joints.  My onc says it is not unusual for people to report feeling a lot older after chemo.  I guess I can live with it, especially as I'm not interested in taking any more medicine that aspirin or ibuprofen and my weekly Herceptin tx (lasting until March). My first mammogram post-chemo will be November 8th.  I know until I get the results that day I will be on tenterhooks, but, as my RO says, it's highly unlikely that anything could have survived the chemo/radiation onslaught I gave it this spring. Hope all of you outh there are doing well.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 06:35PM JulieH wrote: Hi Kimala! Welcome to our thread!  There's not much activity here anymore -- I think most of us finished our treatment and moved on quickly, but I'm glad you've been able to read our stories and get some insight.  It sounds, though, like your journey is turning out to be more trying than most of ours were.  I'm very sorry that that is the case for you. My husband and I have spent the summer dealing with a recurrence of his Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.  It's a scary thing when this beast comes back.  Thankfully, his is very localized, and his onc feels that he will be well-served with the excisional biopsy he had early this month and an upcoming course of radiation. I wish you the very best in the coming months, and hope that your treatment is successful and that the results are lasting for you.   I check back here about once a week if you need someone to vent to.   Best, Julie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: JulieH wrote: Hi everyone!  Got the word from my onco yesterday that I will begin my chemo treatments AC/TH on January 18th.  He's going to start me on a dose dense schedule ACx4 (Neulasta shot 24 hrs later) every two weeks followed by THx4.  I've had my lumpectomy and will go in for re-excision on Dec. 30th.  Chemo teach is sched for Jan. 6 then the treatments a couple of weeks later.  I'm really comfortable with my medical team, especially the onco who got my husband through Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma four years ago.  Guess he didn't expect to see me on the exam table!  If you're starting chemo in January, too, maybe we can start a support thread now and get through this together. "When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive - to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love." - Marcus Aurelius Chemo started 1/18/11. DD A/C x 4 + DD T/H x 4 + weekly Hx52 then rads (completed 7/6/11) Dx 12/10/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 01:22PM JulieH wrote: Welcome to all you newbies -- wish none of us was here!  Hope everyone is so involved in holiday activities that you all are able to at least a little bit take your minds off what's in our future.  My husband and I are flying up to NYC today, a trip that had been planned long before my diagnosis and all the subsequent biopsies, surgeries, doctors' appointments and just plain junk this last month.  I'm hoping to be so busy that the upcoming surgery, doctors' appointments, and chemo can fade a little bit into the background.  It's always in the back of my mind; but it still seems so unreal half the time.  I mean, this can't possibly be me, right? vis0121:  I'll be doing 4 rounds of AC, too.  Then on to 4 rounds of Taxol + Herceptin and taking the herceptin 1 every three weeks for the remainder of the year, since my bc was HER2+.  I've read that the AC can also make eyebrows and lashes fall out, too, in some women -- not sure why some and not others.  Hope you're able to get some rest soon.  I know I was having a hard time getting comfortable after my surgery and sleeping propped up in bed or on the sofa seemed to help some.  Of course, mine wasn't as extensive as yours, since I just had the lumpectomy.  I figure I'll have just gotten comfortable sleeping and being active in time for my re-excision on the 30th.  I'm planning to shave my head, too, once the hair really begins to come out.  At least I can control that! ProudMom:  It is scary, isn't it?  But you're right, the support on this network is phenomenal!  And we will always have each other to sound off to -- to commiserate, to complain, to rejoice when things go well, and to cry with if it ever seems more than we can handle. Tundra:  Welcome!  It's all a whirlwind, isn't it?  And not a good one, I know.  We'll need you to be our resident expert on Taxol, since you're starting it first!  Good luck -- I'll be thinking of you next week.  Check back and let us know how it goes, OK? islandmom: Have you heard anything about a second opinion?  I know what you mean about it seeming like overkill, I wondered that, too.  But my onco explained it really well, saying it's a lot like putting down weedkiller for dandelions.  You may not see any weeds growing, but if the seeds have spread, you want to make sure you get them before they're grown.  He said the invasive cancer is like that -- you may not have any nodes postive, and there may not be any other evidence of tumors, but if any of those cancer cells have gotten into the bloodstream, the only way to catch them is with "weedkiller."  I guess I'm more of the "better safe than sorry" school -- I want this to be the one and only year I ever have to deal with this monster. Well, my best to all of you over the holidays!

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 04:38PM - edited Dec 31, 2010 04:38PM by JulieH Kym61: Thanks for the port info.  I'll give it a couple more days before I really start thinking something's wrong!   Just feels strange -- guess my jugular's not used to having something attached to it. bamamama:  Welcome -- but sure wish you weren't here. What a journey you've had.  It must be frustrating to find yourself back here, especially when the SNB was clear.  But such a good thing that you were insistent about having the new lump checked.  Sometimes we know our bodies better than the doctors -- big surprise. Mine is a power port, too.  My surgeon put in a small one, because I'm small (4'10"), so I gather there are different sizes.  It's centered about midway between my collarbone and my right breast (the BC is in the left side), with the line going from the port to my jugular vein (but that's not too obvious).  There is a noticeable lump, although it's a lot smaller than my husband's port, which is a good inch or more across and you can really see the line running from the port to his vein.  I know, the whole idea kind of gives me the creeps, but from what I gather it's a lot easier to stick the port than it is to try to stick a vein each time, and with a year's worth of herceptin ahead of me, I really don't want them to have to try to find a good vein each week. Apparently, though, it's also very easy to take out when they don't need it any more, so it's definitely not permanent.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 10:05AM JulieH wrote: Welcome Suz, Annie, and Mary Margaret-- Sorry you're here, but maybe there's some strength in numbers? My port is slowly starting to feel more comfortable, still pulling a little bit, but definitely more comfortable.  I know I'll be happy to have it once the weekly Herceptin tx start. Suz:  I grew up in Hillsboro -- don't know if you're from OR, but I'm always finding it's a small world that way.  Think the Ducks can take the championship?  I know my family is rooting for it to happen even though none of us went to the U of OR.  (I did go to summer camp there when I was in Jr. High -- does that count?) Moe0279: What was the Glutamine for?  Is it to counter some of the SE?  So glad the tx are proving to be easier for you than you were expecing.  It's nice to get good news sometimes, isn't it?  Seems like the last month and a half has been nothing but one piece of bad news after another.  Here's to continued lack of SE.  Just placed an order for a Gaila -- thanks again for the info. Annie: Happy to have you here!  No judgement, ever, right?    Support is the name of the game here. So what's a cold cap for?  Is it something to help counteract hair loss?  Something else?  I'm looking for all the information and suggestions I can find. Mary Margaret: Sorry your journey has been so difficult -- here's to hoping that the next few months are easier for you.  From what I've heard, hair starts to come out around day 14 (maybe a little longer).  And keep talking!  That's what we're here for, right? CityKitty:  If you're still with us, good luck with your first tx tomorrow.  Hope everything goes well for you and that SE are minimal to nonexistent.

Everyone:  I can't tell you how much it means to be able to read your words.  The advice everyone has, the experience of those who've been through this before, how everyone is coping -- it makes such a huge difference. Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 03:20PM JulieH wrote: Islandmom: Gladthe S/Es weren't too bad to begin with. I'll bet it was the steroids causing the hunger and inability to sleep. Hope that's cleared up a little. Have you stopped this round of steroids yet? vis0121: Must be a relief to have a date. Glad you're not having to wait too long to begin. Good luck with the port placement. It can be painful at first, but gets better in a few days. I hear that days 3 & 4 on the AC are the roughest, so I'm planning to take them off from work for my first round, anyway, to give myself the space to deal with it if necessary. UTMom2014: Good for you for walking afterwards -- I'm hoping to be able to do that. I'm not an active person normally, but I would really like to do something, maybe get back into some yoga at the "Y." Did they do the Emend in an IV? Iasked my chemo nurse about it, and she said they always go with the pill form of Emend. I suspect that's so that we bear the burden of the cost, and not the cancer center. Seems like the IV would be more effective. Were you able to keep the nausea at bay? moe0279: Maybe you'll get lucky with your hair -- that would be one nice surprise in a long list of bad ones. AliT: were you able to begin your treatment on Wednesday? Hope the infection cleared up in time. MaryMeg: Were you able to sing your solo today? (Yesterday for you?)  How have you been post-treatment? JeanH: Hope your cold clears up soon. My parents (in Florida) have bad ones and sound miserable, and my assistant at work is getting over the flu. 'Tis the season for them, isn't it? My grade was given in both my core needle biopsy and the path report from the lumpectomy. Here is something I found online that describes the different grades. Do any of them resemble any of the parts of your report?Grade 1 (lowest) Well-differentiated breast cells; cells generally appear normal and are not growing rapidly; cancer arranged in small tubules. Grade 2 Moderately-differentiated breast cells; have characteristics between Grade 1 and Grade 3 tumors. Grade 3 (highest) Poorly differentiated breast cells; Cells do not appear normal and tend to grow and spread more aggressively. amyK: How are you feeling a few days out from your tx? Have you been able to keep things under control? The closer I get, the more trepidation I feel. As always, it's the not knowing that's the worst. islandmom: How wonderful for you that you were able to go to your son's confirmation. Islandmom - 1, Chemo - 0! jcornes: With any luck (for you!) you won't need to join us. Good luck! ProudMom_Wife: When my DH was on chemo, he had a very bad time with constipation -- one particularly bad episode where we thought we would have to go to the hospital. Anyhow, as a natural alternative to the chemical laxitives, his chemo nurses recommended warm prune juice with a sliver of butter. Sounds gross, but he swears by it now. I'm up for anything, and a natural solution is a good one for me. Your DH sounds like a wonderful support.  AmyMac: Welcome! Just wish we all could meet under better circumstances. Another lady on the board is also havin the T+Carb -- Steph42. Not sure if she's still with us or not . . .? So glad you're having minimal SEs -- hope that continues for you. I, too, am considering going drastic with hair color. I got my hair cut very short a few weeks ago and think I'll color it just before my first tx. I had a couple of girls at my middle school say I should dye it jet black and get some piercings . . . But I was thinking white blonde or bright red. I'll only have it for a couple of weeks after, so why not? Best of luck to our Monday starters: WarriorPrincess24, anniemomofthree, and lee7. You will all be in our thoughts tomorrow. {{{{{{HUGS}}}}}} all around!

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 03:50PM JulieH wrote: slcst12: So sorry to hear what the tx did to your mom.  NHL is scary in and of itself, and I know they try to hit it hard, it's just too bad that what gets the disease under control can cause so many problems.  My DH and I are lucky his tx didn't leave him worse off than the neuropathy that won't go away.  I know the more I read about the collateral long-term effects that some of our drugs can cause the more scared I get . . .  I know I'm doing the right thing, but it certainly does add to the stress.  I can't blame you for not wanting to add another drug into the mix. WarriorPrincess24:  Glad to hear your tx was uneventful today.  You're a brave soul to give yourself the Neulasta shots.  I just was asking my DH today if he could give me a shot if necessary and he said yes.  But I'm pretty sure I couldn't do it myself.  Good luck on your expansion.  May I ask -- is it painful or uncomfortable?  Maybe neither? Welcom webu -- sorry you're here!  It's nice that your infusion center is a pleasant place.  That will go a long way to helping you to relax! UTMom2014:  So sorry you were feeling so rotten today.  I really recommend trying the prune juice/butter -- crazy as it sounds it really worked for my husband.  Eating a couple of prunes a day helps too.  The food thing is oneof the aspects of all this that bothers me the most -- am hoping not to be so affected, but have real a lot of posts on other boards from women who've lost a lot of weight because they just couldn't face the food.  I do hope it gets better for you.  But rest if you need to. bamamama2 (karen):  My records show you start tx tomorrow.  Good luck -- hope by this time tomorrow night you're feeling great.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 06:13PM JulieH wrote: Welcome bdavis! I know you wish you weren't here . . . (Well, I'll bet you wish you weren't here!) Sounds like you're well on your way to getting going. Wish I could tell you more about the diff. between Taxol and Taxotere. Same family of drugs is about all I know. Maybe someone else can shed some light? Melissa: Hope that tumor is smaller -- sometimes they can respond just that quickly! Good luck! baf4292: Sounds like things have been going well for you. You must have been relieved to be able to work. I know how good it felt to go back to work after each of my surgeries. I find that it really helps take my mind off of everything else to concentrate on the everyday things of working with students and teachers. Hope you continue to feel as well as you have. ProudMom_Wife: I used the Miralax after my 2nd surgery (the vicodin constipated me) and it took a couple of days to kick in, but when it did, it did with a vengeance. Anyhow, it works! UTMom2014: I can't imagine ice cream not tasting good -- it will be a huge disappointment to me if I can't enjoy my ice cream!  Seriously, we have this wonderful gelato shop in town; maybe I should go in the next couple of days while I can still enjoy it! I've read different things on vitamins -- I'd be interested to hear what your onco says. Has anyone heard anything from their doctors about not eating soy products? I'm vegetarian, so soy is a big source of protein for me . . . I was so excited this moring to hear that Michael Douglas was tumor-free. Good for him! It is a lot of weight to lose, but I don't think it's unusual. We need to make sure we're getting enough protein and good calories -- must be hard to do when everything tastes off and our stomachs are queasy.  Small meals and good snacks throughout the day is what I've heard helps.  Looking at my notes, doesn't look like any of us are starting tomorrow. If I've missed someone -- sorry, and hope it goes well! But to everyone -- sleep well tonight and may tomorrow be free of stress and SE.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 05:53AM JulieH wrote: Beckie:  Sorry it was such a chore!  Thankfully I was out of it completely when they did my port.  I was having my re-excision at the same time.  I really don't think I could have been awake for it -- I'm way too squeamish.  Best of luck to you tomorrow! Tundra:  I agree.  But then, everyone I've ever known personally who has had BC has been under 50 -- and now me, too.  Don't know if anyone saw it this morning, but the Today show had a 4-year-old on who underwent a modified radical mastectomy at the age of 3 when they found a secretory form of BC.  Good God!  That's young. The fatigue hit me with a vengeance last night.  Otherwise I'd been feeling pretty good, but by 9 pm I could hardly keep my head up; and I'm usually a real night person.  I was in bed at 9:30 and out about a minute and a half after that.  I was just surprised it came on so fast; just one tx into this whole thing.  My DH said I'll need to get used to it . . .  And now this morning, I'm feeling borderline woozy again after feeling pretty good that way yesterday.  I'll just see how it progresses. sciencegirl:  Thrush is the worst.  I hope it's not too painful for you.  Have you asked the doc for "magic mouthwash?"  It's basically something they compound at the pharmacy.  I think it's mostly the benedryl/maalox mix with other things, also.  That can help with the pain.  Diflucan should help, too.  I had both when I had thrush a few years back (not BC related, obviously). Betsey:  We do have to find the silver lining where we can, don't we?  I've always found that Benedryl helps best with my allergies.  (I'm allergic to cats, but I refuse to get rid of my two fur-babies!) ProudMom:  So GLAD your doctor went to bat for you with the insurance companies.  I can't stand it when the insurance tries to dictate the medical coverage we get.  Seems like the onc's office would know better with each individual patient that the insurance company would from possibly hundreds of miles away . . .  But that's my big soapbox, so I'll get off of it now.  Good luck to Jane_UK for your first tx today!  Hope it goes well for you!

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:07AM JulieH wrote: webu: I hate it when my cable/internet goes down. Unfortunately, it used to happen a lot with the Knology we're on; not so much recently, though. It's good that you didn't have too much nausea, but sorry you're getting the mouth sores. Have you tried the baking soda/salt/water rinse? I tried it, but the thought of using it makes me gag at this point, so I just can't face it.  I've read women who swear by it, though, and my chemo nurse gave me the recipe, so it must work. It's just 1 Tbs of baking soda, 1 tsp of salt, and warm water. Tastes awful, though, at least as far as I'm concerned, but I've never been able to stomach gargling with salt water, either. I was able to get some l-glutamine capsules at our local health food store and have been opening those up, mixing the contents with water, and rinsing with that then swallowing. My mouth (tongue esp.) is tingling, but no sores yet. Another thing I use right before bed is the Biotene gel (not just the rinse). It's kind of like eating a mouthful of vaseline, but it does moisturize the mouth before going to sleep. Proud_Mom: I have been keeping a record of everything I eat and when I take the meds -- can't see any patterns yet since it's really too early, but I can see that I don't know how I'll ever survive on what I have been able to eat!  I got the weight boost from the steroids and that's coming down now, so some small consolation. Betsey: Hope the Neulasta pain never got above a dull ache for you. No, thrush looks like white patches all over your mouth and throat and hurts like the worst sore throat you've ever had. I remember feeling like I was swallowing past razor blades when I had it. Hope yours doesn't go that direction! Heather: Sorry you had such a pincushion day. Makes me very happy I have the port. Thank god for the vein ninja! Good luck with the queasiness. Small meals more frequently eaten is supposed to help. Do I detect a note of sarcasm in your inquiry into what might be making you feel cruddy? I just felt like hell yesterday and found myself apologizing to my DH for how "unfun" I'm going to be for the next few months. He is such a sweetie, just reassured me that the most important thing right now is getting through this, and we can "worry" about fun in about 16 weeks. He's been here, he does understand, and that may be the only way I consider myself lucky here -- at least he's never going to lose patience with how I'm feeling. Doing better today, at least for now. Just wondering how going back to work on Monday is going to go . . .
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:34AM JulieH wrote: slcst12:  Your little boy's comment brought tears to my eyes -- the little ones always get right to the heart of things, don't they.  It's one reason I miss working in an elementary school -- the hugs from kindergartners are truly special! I've been taking the Claritin for the Neulasta and hate to think how much it would have hurt without.  The pain is a lot better today, though.  I had it esp. bad in my shoulders and breast bone.  I think we all need to remember your "mantra" about us doing this for us -- to give us our best chance -- because I can see where it would be easy to give up. I had that conversation with my DH last night, too. Best of luck, everyone.  Here's hoping the SEs do nothing but get better for everyone!

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 06:05AM - edited Jan 22, 2011 06:06AM by JulieH UTMom: How are you feeling today? I'm so sorry you had to spend so much time in the hosp. Seriously, constipation is terrible, especially when one is used to being really regular. Hope that's better now. I feel bad that you had to go through the hair loss at the hospital, instead of being able to deal with it how you would have preferred. Those franceluxe wraps are nice, though, aren't they? Now you need to sleep -- as much as possible, probably, to get your strength back. I'll be thinking of you! Beckie: Wow -- now that's a productive first tx! :-) Did the Lunesta put a dent in the steroids? Good luck with the neulasta today. AliT: Another beautiful picture from one of our January sisters! The Neulasta is painful. I'm just starting to see a lessening of the pain this morning from my shot on Wed. Easily the thing that makes me feel the worst. I didn't get any headaches, thankfully. Hope yours have gotten better. Welcome cblue715: Sorry your first tx ended up in such an uncomfortable place. My DH had the same problem when he was going through tx. Be sure to get that stool softener in, it should help. Also, and I know I keep saying this, but warm prune juice with a sliver of butter melted in it is an excellent natural way to go to help constipation. Not too appetizing, but DH and his chemo nurse swear by it. Good luck with next week! suz3: Good luck today -- here's hoping you feel as good as every other day since tx#1. webu: Sorry about the port! Did they say whether or not they would expect this to be an ongoing problem? I hope not, for your sake! Hope the Leviquin makes a difference -- that's a high powered one, from what I hear. baf4292: I'm beginning to envy your cipro regime. This bone pain is miserable. Hope you have a wonderful time at your son's birthday dinner, and good luck with the buzz tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 02:31PM JulieH wrote: slcst12:  So sorry the SEs have been so harsh.  I sympathize with the Neulasta pain.  I thought I was finally over it yesterday but it woke me up this morning in my knees. Today I'm getting the pinball pains:  knees to hips to headache and back around again.  I'm finding myself walking much more slowly than I normally would.  Hope no one wants me quickly on the other side of my library tomorrow -- they're not getting me quickly. For the nausea I had the tri-fold Emend pack from which I took the first pill on the day of the tx and pills two and three on the day after and the third day.  They gave me Decadron and Aloxi in IV the day of tx and at home I've had Compazine and Ativan in addition to the Emend.  I haven't hesitated to take the Compazine; the first four days I was taking it pretty much every four to six hours.  The day after tx I took an Ativan in the middle of the day and took an Ativan every night with the Compazine from Tuesday through Friday nights. I've also had ginger ale to drink (just realizing I didn't get any at the store today . . .) plus ginger tea.  I've also really tried to eat small amounts throughout the day, even though nothing sounded good.  I've read that small meals (hardly a meal, just something to put in my mouth) throughout the day is a good idea, because you really don't want to let your stomach get empty.  I've been queasy, but thankfully have not thrown up (I REALLY don't do well with vomit . . .).  There hasn't been a day when my stomach hasn't felt like it was on the edge.  I also haven't tried to do much (pain wouldn't really let me) during the day.  Easy because I took the time off from work and I don't have kids and my DH has done all his own cooking. I have also read that the younger you are, the worse the nausea tends to be.  Under 50 seems to be the cutoff I've seen.  Now, I'm under 50 (almost 45 here), but I'm not as young as you.  I've lost about four pounds this week, but at 4'11", I can afford to lose some weight and not have it be a big problem. My franceluxe headwrap is a melange of greens and aquas in a paisley pattern.  Really quite lovely.  I do wish they weren't as expensive as they are, I'd get a few more because they had so many pretty patterns. Hang in there -- Wednesday night I, too, asked my DH if this was going to be worth it because I felt like hell.  Of course I know it is, but I'm a week and a half from my next tx and I'm already dreading it.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 02:50AM JulieH wrote: MaryMeg:  I was watching a program we have here called "House Hunters: International" on which this couple was moving from Kin Kin, Australia to the Great Barrier Island and I was struck by the intense beauty of your part of the world.  It must be a constant feast for the senses (wind notwithstanding).  I hadn't heard about the scarf rings -- I'll bet they do the trick, though.  I've tried on a couple of my scarves and used a regular headband once to see if it would help hold the scarf in place and I think it would do a good job. Well, off to work this morning.  My sleeping pill only gave me 7 hours overnight so I had a little extra time to kill this morning. Hope everyone has a good day!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 04:07PM - edited Jan 24, 2011 04:10PM by JulieH Felt good to be back at work today. Most of the nausea and pain are gone, so I was able to go pretty much at top speed until about 2:00 when I went back and worked at my desk. As always, I think it was good to get back and keep myself busy. sciencegirl: I know you can make it --we all can. It might not be easy, but every day we're getting there. I agree about the mammogram baseline age. The earlier we catch it, ultimately the less it will cost, if cost is the major issue. I happen to think that catching it early is reason enough.Kym61: Hope your new haircut is easy for you to get used to. I was just talking to my DH about shaving my head this weekend. I like the idea of my deciding when it's going to go and I think it's time. Crummy deal about the period! I would think if we do go into chemopause, since there won't be a period all the junk that goes along with it should go away too. Of course, we may be trading bloating and cramps for night sweats and hot flashes . . . hsgray: Those anti-nauseals do wipe you out, don't they? The Ativan I take is especially sleep-inducing. I am finally starting to feel hungry, day 6 post-tx, but a lot of things (like chocolate), aren't all that appealing anymore. I suppose that's going to get worse as treatment continues? Glad you and Kym didn't have horrible Neulasta pain and that you were able to sleep, finally. moe0279: Good luck with the neuropathy -- wish I had some advice other than to make sure your doc is aware of it.AimeeMac: I've always heard that the SEs are cumulative, so I guess I'm expecting things to get worse; at least the fatigue side of things. Anyone else who can speak to this? I love the Wilson and Annette Benning references, ladies! What was up with her last week? Anyhow, I'm amazed at how ratty my short hair looks when I get up in the morning, although I will say that a brush through it usually does an OK job of straightening it out. I'm off to cook my DH some dinner -- I think I should while I feel up to it. He's really not much of a cook . . .(big understatement). Hope everyone has a good day tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 04:23PM JulieH wrote: Had my first Taxol/Herceptin today -- 6 hours in the infusion chair = boredom!  My onc had me take steroids 12 then 6 hours before treatment then they gave me a Katril push for nausea, benadryl, more Decadron (IV this time) 3 hours for the Taxol, more benadryl, then 1.5 hours for the "loading dose" (first dose) of Herceptin.  No allergic reactions so far.  The onc did warn me about the pain and changes in nail beds. I'll see what happens.  This Herceptin is the first of 52 weekly -- guess I'll have to make it a habit. For those with hand issues from the AC, it's what's known as hand/foot syndrome.  It happens when the capillaries in the hands/feet break and allow the Adriamycin to leak into the tissues.  It causes pain, itching, peeling, and in severe cases bad, supurating blisters.  It can hold up tx or cause tx to need to be stopped completely if it happens in earlier tx.  I had that last week and my hands were miserable this weekend.  Got some hydrocortisone hand cream to use and it's much better now.  My onc confirmed what I had found online, that now that the Adriamycin is done, it shouldn't be a problem.  Apparently the Taxol doesn't cause it the way the Adriamycin does. I have a MUGA scan scheduled for Monday next.  Can anyone tell me anything about the process?  How long it lasts?  What to expect? My periods, too, have stopped completely.  The last was Jan. 13, just before my first A/C tx.  I've been wondering if it's going to be permanent, too.  At 45, I guess I wouldn't mourn its loss all than much.  I'm only 1% ER+ and don't know if Tamoxifen is in my future or not.  Guess I'd better ask the onc about that.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 04:13PM JulieH wrote: Marcia:  I'm glad you're feeling better now but am sorry you're having such a terrible time.  I know that the A/C I was on wiped me out and, by the 4th tx I could barely function.  The pain I've had with the 1st Taxol tx was pretty vicious and the fatigue was strong, too.  If it's not one thing, it's another, I know.  I sympathize with your saying you don't know if you'd go into this again given your experiences.  I know I would have a hard time putting myself through it again if I should ever have a recurrence.  I guess that's the one thing that keeps me going in the face of 6 weeks of radiation and a full year of weekly Herceptin -- I don't EVER want this crud to come back, and this is the best way I know how to keep that from happening.  Take care and keep the memory of that daffodil in mind.  Spring is almost here, treatments will be ending sooner, rather than later, and then we can all get our lives back. Best to all.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2011 07:25AM JulieH wrote: On AC, the liquids were hard for me, too.  I love diet Dr. Pepper and a good class of ice water, but almost no liquid tastes GOOD now, and it's been a month since my last AC.  I guess the taste will come back.  I had to force myself to drink a glass of water each time I would go into the bathroom.  Amazingly, tea seems to be the most palatable to me these days -- both hot and cold.  Do whatever it takes to get your liquids.  At one point my husband ratted me out to my chemo nurses about not getting near enough liquids and they said if necessary I could come in and they'd give me IV liquids.  I didn't want to do that, so I've really made an effort to drink. As for the nausea, with me it was constant and the time it lasted got longer with each tx.  By the end I was on Emend, Zofran, Pfenergan (I had to stop the Compazine because I started having uncontrollable spasms in my legs and feet) and Ativan just at night.  I would take some combination of all of these for nearly a week and then stopped so that I could function at work the next week.  The nausea that second week was still there, but would subside into the background eventually. The thing about food was that I never felt hungry on AC.  I knew I was, but I just didn't feel it, if that makes any sense.  Once I ate, I felt better, but getting that first bit of food into my mouth was a struggle.  Starchy foods were the most appealing, but by my fourth AC tx in my off week I was actively craving protein.  I think I was living on string cheese.  Sweets are almost completely unappetizing to me right now and I normally LOVE donuts, ice cream, and, especially, chocolate.  I MISS chocolate, but it just doesn't taste right.  Maybe by Easter . . . AC is hard.  You may feel like quitting (I sure did), but you can get through it.  Just hang in there and remember we're here for you.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 04:45PM JulieH wrote: Proud_Mom: Had my 12th of 33 rads today.  I'm feeling pretty tired this afternoon, but don't know how much of that is the rads and how much only sleeping about 7 1/2 hours last night.  I have some pain in my breast, and the skin is feeling kind of "itchy" this evening, but so far not too bad.  I'm using the aquaphor my RO recommended, so hopefully that will help keep things under control.  I was digging around online yesterday and found some, to me, distressing pictures and information of what can happen to our skin towards the end of this.  I see the RO on Weds and am planning to ask her if my chest has much chance of looking like putrefying cooked meat in 3 1/2 weeks . . .  I know, I shouldn't dig like that, but I'm also a little peeved that no one has really told me exactly what I can expect in terms of skin reaction.  I wish they could show us pictures of their average patients.  I always do better when I know exactly what to expect, even if the news isn't pretty, because then I can prepare myself mentally. Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 05:45PM JulieH wrote: Another possible wrinkle in this journey: I've been having pain in my right arm (the side with my port) for about three weeks now.  I thought at first it was just muscle strain, but it's not localized in the deltoid, rather, the whole arm aches.  I thought it might be related to the neuropathy I've had in my thumb since early in the Taxol tx, so I waited to talk with the onc. When I told him today, he said it was probably not neuropathy, but said it could be a couple of other things: 1.  The catheter from my port might possibly have migrated from where it is supposed to stay into the artery supplying my arm, or 2.  Possibly a blood clot (less likely). He's scheduled an ultrasound (to rule out the blood clot) and a chest x-ray (to check on the catheter). Have any of you, in your readings around this site and elsewhere or in your discussions with your oncs, run into any mention of this? I'd love to say just take the *%$* thing out, but I really need to keep it for the next 8 months while I get the Herceptin tx. Because the fun never ends . . .
