Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 06:13AM JulieH wrote: Hello, all! Welcome Marcia.  Glad you've joined this group that no one wants to be a part of, but it's good to have you here.  My head was cold last night in my bedroom (so much so I had to wear a cap all night), so I can only imagine what it feels like up in your neck of the woods.  Lorenar:  The Biotene really does work -- I don't much like the after taste, but it makes the dryness better.  Also, the gel is good right before you sleep.  Just put a little in your mouth and smoosh it around your teeth, cheeks, and roof of your mouth.  It keeps the mouth moisturized throughout the night. sciencegirl:  My head feels pretty good, actually.  And I was surprised at how soft the stubble is.  Don't know why I was surprised, thinking about it, it's not like it felt like beard hair when it was long!  It actually feels kind of velvety when you rub with the grain, so to speak. We went to lunch yesterday afternoon and then last night to Barnes & Noble and I didn't feel too self-conscious. The scarf got a little warm and I was happy to be able to just take it off when I got home.  Hope your buzz goes well, whenever you decide you're ready.  MaryMeg:  Sleep would be welcome, I'm sure.  Hope you're able to get something to help you feel less zombie-like soon. NancyFL:  Glad your SEs have been so manageable.  Hope it continues for you! Moe:  I had that shaky feeling after just one AC tx.  Could it have something to do with your fatigue?  I know I get the shakes when I'm bone-tired, and you sound like you're at that point.  Get lots of rest, if you can.  Take care! slcst:  Good luck this week!  They adjusted your anti-nausea regimen, didn't they?  Hope that makes a huge difference for you.  It's scary going into the 2nd tx, knowing we're going to feel pretty rotten and knowing that we still need to do this.  Usually, our instincts tell us to run away from things like this that hurt us, and here we are, voluntarily putting ourselves in the infusion chair.  So, as I'm typing this post I look over on the floor and the little white, fuzzy cap I left on my bed when I got up is sitting on the middle of the floor.   I think my cats have been after it.    Must have looked like a great cat toy!

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 06:45PM JulieH wrote: Lee7:  I know what you're saying about missing work for appts.  I had 68 days of sick leave built up,and I feel that slipping away . . .  Our first day back after break is tomorrow, and I'm taking off as a result of my 2nd surgery.  I hate missing work, too -- I agree that that's been almost more stressful than some of the other things.  At school, We're not supposed to wear head coverings, either, but I talked specifically with my principal and told him I didn't think I'd be comfortable with a wig and asked permission to wear hats and scarves and he said that would be fine -- even suggested having a "hats for Ms. H" day to help us raise funds for our Relay for Life team, which I've chaired for the past three years.  Talk with your principal, unless you're comfortable with a wig, in which case it isn't a big issue.  Hopefully they'll be understanding.  And I hope your co-workers step up, too.  It makes such a big difference to have a big support network at work.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 04:25PM JulieH wrote: Moe0279: Even without chemo I'm on an emotional rollercoaster -- find myself crying at the smallest provocation. So, the chemo probably doesn't help, and I've read a lot of posts reminding us to remember that the steroids we get w/ the tx can wreak havod with our emotions -- think of athletes and 'roid rage. So, cry when you need to, and realize that it will probably get easier eventually. Also, a note on the neuropathy. If you have tingling or pain, don't hesitate to let your onco know. My husband was on the drug Velcade for his lymphoma and that is also notorious for causing neuropathy. Our onco was very responsive when he found that my DH was starting to feel it and, if the lymphoma hadn't gone into (essentially) remission, he would have stopped the treatments and changed to a different drug. DH still has bad pain in his feet, 3 years later, so don't let it get bad. The docs want to know when it's happening. And please, you NEVER have to apologize for complaining. That's what this forum is for -- for us to air our feelings (good, bad, hopeful, angry, depressed, funny) as we take this journey. There will never be anyone would judge you for letting your feelings out. baf4292: So glad you had a good experience with the wig shopping, finally. The last thing any of us needs is to be stonewalled at an unhelpful shop when we're dealing with one of the most emotional things any of us will ever go through. Just another sort of thing that would make me cry right now (see above ). And don't let those anti-nauseals wear off! Hope you're feeling good today, too. suz3: Thanks! Yes, I got good news today. While they did find the extra area of DCIS, the 2.5 mm margin is satisfying everyone, so NO MORE surgery for me (at least not now, anyhow!). GO DUCKS! UTMom2014: Oh yeah, work is definitely the best medicine! Nothing like getting back into the work groove to take my mind off of the BC. Hope this post finds you feeling good after the tx. MaryMeg: Loved your reference to the Stones -- made me laugh!  Glad the tx went smoothly for you -- may they all be like that! slcst12: I think the pinata idea sounds great -- could make what would otherwise be potentially scary for the kids something fun. I love what your friend had to say about us choosing to take control of this whole situation. It's so true. We could decide not to do this, but I'm sure that each of us feels that this is giving us our best chance at NEVER having to face it again. ProudMom_Wife: Hope you are feeling better this evening. My onco nurse yest. during the chemo teach said to stay on top of the nausea and keep taking those anti-nauseals 'cause it's a lot easier to control it if you don't let it creep up on you. I'm all for taking as much medicine as possible to stay ahead of it so I don't have to play catch up. And I'm really not a medicine taker; but I figure this is a special situation. So glad you haven't had any Neulasta pain! I asked my onco yesterday about the Claritin for pain and he says he sees it working all the time. He said he doesn't know why and, even if it is a placebo effect, so what? If it's working, it's working. Hope you continue pain free. I got my bandanas and Gaila in the mail today.  Love the scarves and the Gaila is really nice -- tried it on and I think it's going to work well.  (But, as always, felt myself choking up . . . )  It was so nice that after this free one, I think I'll probably get another couple for variety.  Still want to contact Franceluxe, too -- those look really pretty, as well. Have a lovely weekend, everyone. May it be relatively SE free for those of you in tx already.

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 03:40PM JulieH wrote: Day 2 of first T/H tx.  No real nausea to speak of (yayy!!), but GI issues: heartburn pretty bad this evening (just took a Pepcid) and my gut seems to be unhappy -- hope it doesn't turn into diarrhea . . .  Sounds like what you were dealing with, Tammy.  Also, the tips of my fingers are really painful.  Anyone else on the Taxol have that after just one tx?  DH thinks I should call the onc, but, really, what can he do?  It's there; it'll either go away or it won't.  I'm thinking I'll just let the nurses know when I'm in for my H tx next week and see what they say.  I did run out of energy mid-afternoon and slept for an hour and a half -- just couldn't keep my eyes open. Thanks for the info on the MUGA scan.  Love those radioactive boxes (had one with my sentinel node biopsy), esp. in light of the nuclear issues going on around the world.  I feel so bad for all that's going on in Japan right now -- hope things are under control for them soon. slcst:  My onc is keeping me on the Neulasta -- said that with the DD it was a good idea.  But you're doing the DD, too, aren't you?  Or are you going to weekly Taxol?  Hope you're feeling well after your first tx. citykitty:  I think that's why my time in the chair was longer; I'm going in every other week, so the dose is larger than it would be if I were going in weekly.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 04:08PM JulieH wrote: jcoutee:  MaryMeg, on this thread, had a prophylactic BMX a few years ago and was then diagnosed this year with the breast cancer, so it's not a 100% cure.  I was dismayed to hear that, and if I was, I can only imagine how she must have felt.  I, myself, had the lumpectomy and felt entirely comfortable with that decision, especially as I am going through the AC+TH and will have the rads, even though it's on my left side, so I'm hitting it with everything available.  Cosmetically, my breasts were big enough to get a good result with the lumpectomy and reexcision, so that was a consideration, too.  If I'd been a B cup rather than the D cup, I might have felt differently.  Lastly, I don't think I'd want to do the reconstruction if I had a MX -- just wondered how exams, biopsies, scans, etc. would work with a foreign body in there should there ever be a reoccurence.  (Had a friend, who's never had breast cancer, start in on how stupid she thought someone else was for deciding NOT to have reconstruction after a MX and I cut her short and said it's a very personal decision and that I don't think I'd do reconstruction.  She dropped the subject pretty quickly . . .) Once again, as everyone has said, go with what your gut is telling you, because it IS such a personal decision.  Do the thing you think you'll have the fewest regrets with.  And never let anyone tell you whatever decision you make is wrong. Tammy:  I tell myself once I feel better I'm going to make a REAL effort to start exercising again and doing yoga.  I have been vegetarian for nearly 20 years, but my diet still hasn't been that great (see my earlier post about loving sweets and chocolate!) and I'd like to change that.  I haven't put any weight on since starting chemo and, while I'd take 5 to 7 pounds off after each AC, I would put it back on with the starchy foods that didn't nauseate me more on my weeks off, so I've held pretty steady.  That said, I need to lose weight.  Like you, I'm 4'11", and really should weigh about 20 - 25 pounds less than I do -- the extra fat in my body isn't going to help the ER+ status of my BC.  I'm just so tired (and frequently in pain from the Taxol) right now that I'm happy to be able to walk at all around the house and to eat anything that doesn't take too much preparation.  Four more weeks, though, and I should be past the worst of the SEs from my last tx, and I'm planning to start taking better care of myself then.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 11:09AM JulieH wrote: Well, I'm back from my first AC treatment and so far so good. I took my Emend this morning and they gave me Decadron and Aloxi in the infusion to counteract the nausea and, while my tummy feels a little tentative, no problems yet. I took a claritin when I got home in preparation for tomorrow's Neulasta shot. No Benadryl with this, so wasn't sleepy, but I do have a prescription for a sleeping pill for tonight, in case the steroids keep me up. This was the first time they'd accessed my port and it worked like a charm. I'd slathered the Emla cream on it an hour before and by the time she poked me, it barely felt like a pinch -- gotta love that lidocaine!  All in all, the infusion took about 2 hours: 1/2 hour for the pre-meds; 1/2 hour for the Adriamycin (they infuse it here, not a push), and 1 hour for the Cytoxan. I came home and ate and then brushed my teeth and rinsed my mouth out with that nasty baking soda/salt rinse they gave me a recipe for. Hope it works, 'cause I'd hate to be putting that stuff in my mouth every time I eat for nothing. I'm susceptible to mouth sores anyhow, so I want to do everything I can to avoid them. I had thrush once, and that was miserable with a capital M -- also something to avoid if at all possible. Oh, another thing: when they did the saline and heparin flush in my port, I got a funny taste in my mouth (actually, just the right side) and smell in my nose, kind of like a cross between vinegar and lemons . . . Not bad, just strange. Also, I'm trying to get at least 2 liters of water a day and I had to pee 5 times while at the cancer center (once it was pink from the Adriamycin). Hope that's not TMI, but just in case some of you are wondering, with the liquids they're filling us with plus trying to stay hydrated don't be surprised! Oh, I'm about three hours out now, and am really noticing that my mouth and throat are dryer than normal. Anyone else experience it that quickly? UTMom: So sorry about the WBC -- makes me happy my doc has just sched the shot without waiting. He may have done that since I'm at a school all day (when I'm actually at work). Did you feel bad and go to the doc's to find out what was up, or did they just find it at a regular office visit? Hope it picks up for you soon. Definitely keep us posted! JeanH: I sympathize with your not being a morning person! :-) No laughing about the turtle here -- they're just as much a loved pet as a cuddly dog or cat. My assistant at school has three turtles and it sounds as if they have as much personality as any other pet. I just don't think I could give myself a shot; I'm pretty squeamish that way. Interesting about them not grading the ILC. I wonder why? MaryMeg: Love the new picture! Moe0279: You sound like you're doing great! And good for you for doing what YOU'RE most comfortable with. My only problem with the scarves is that I'm going to have to iron the cotton ones, and I really don't like to iron (it's part of my housework phobia, I think). I'd love to hear how things go at school with the scarf; I'll be facing that in a couple of weeks! Tundra: Welcome back! Do I read this right, you've moved? In the middle of all of this? Must have been stressful! Thanks for the info about the solvent, that's definitely interesting to know. Great news about the BC responding to the tx -- once again, it's good to know that we're going through this and getting positive results! Never too much detail -- thanks for posting. ck_moma: Doesn't seem fair that the wig would look better on the model head, does it? I hear they can really shape it up, though. Good luck! It's pretty amazing the amount of meds we're all taking, isn't it. I look at my bathroom counter and wonder how I'll ever keep it straight. I may have to break down and get one of those pill organizers. Glad to hear that your SEs have been manageable! Good luck to our starters tomorrow: suz3 and Sylvia_62 (if you are able to start). {{{{{HUGS}}}}} to everyone -- we're here when you need to talk!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 12:22PM JulieH wrote: Heather:  Welcome!  Sorry you're here, but it's a great place to "hang out" and find support from folks who really can understand what you're dealing with. This is the first time I've heard of the Triptorelin -- may I ask what kind of drug that is?  I think you look great!  I've said it before and I'll say it again -- I'm really beginning to think that women look fantastic with no hair; and I'm not just saying that!  I sympathize with you about things coming out of the blue.  My family has no history of cancer other than melanoma (my dad is very fair skinned and red-headed) and chronic lymphocitic leukemia developing in two elderly relatives after the age of 80 (my mother's side of the family are very long-lived; my grandma will turn 97 this June).  Where did mine come from?  Who knows . . .  Good luck tomorrow! Haven't heard from vis0121, but I'm thinking lots of good thoughts for her.  Hang in there! Aimee:  As MaryMeg said, the Claritin (I actually bought the Wal-Green's store brand, same thing and a few dollars cheaper) helps to control the bone pain that can come from the Neulasta.  I asked my onc about it, too, and he said he has seen it help in numerous cases.  So, I took one today and I'll take one each day for a few days and keep my fingers crossed.  The Benadryl is almost always given (from what I've read) with Taxol because of the allergic reactions that so many folks get.  My husband had it with his tx (Rituxan) and it put him to sleep for hours, but he never had any bad allergic reactions, so it was definitely worth it.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2011 06:55PM JulieH wrote: Melissa:  I was mentally ready to give in after my 2nd DD A/C, too.  It's hard -- a lot of us know that.  Actually, it's worse than hard; it's really awful. I had to put my head down and gut it out.  There were nights my husband sat with me as I cried and said I didn't think I'd make it.  He'd hold my hand and just let me cry and gave me the space to feel like crap.  And you're right, as I'd get closer to my tx day, it would get harder to face.  I, too, was out from Tuesday to Friday of my tx weeks and would go back to work the next week, even when the nausea and fatigue stayed with me through the off week, too.  Do your best, rest when you need to, cry when it gets to be too much.  A/C will be one of the hardest things you will ever have to force yourself to do.  Come here when you can (I found I didn't have the energy to face the computer most days) for support.  We're here for you.  You can get through it, but it sure isn't easy.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 04:50AM JulieH wrote: Knee pain got me up this morning -- feels like a bad case of arthritis.  But at least the hip/shoulder pain has calmed down.  MaryMeg:  You make me laugh!  I can imagine the kids drawing on your head.  My cousin and I taped my grandmother snoring when we were very young, and I'm not sure she ever forgave us.   It's just the sort of thing that kids will do!  Speaking of kids, one of my coworkers' little girls (she's 10) has already donated twice to the locks of love program and looks like she's growing her hair out again for another round.  She's a sweetie and has been concerned about me since her mom told her about my situation.  She wanted to bring me something like chocolate but was aware that I might not feel like eating things like that.  Kids amaze me constantly -- they can surprise you when you least expect it with the depth of their hearts.  Even middle school kids like the ones I work with. UTMom:  Glad the prune juice worked.  Was it terrible to drink?  Thanks for the "twist" tip, too.  I used to love to do that when I was a kid (as a child of the 70s I loved to watch "Happy Days") and it looks like it would be great exercise in the comfort of my living room.  I got the Neulasta shot in my arm, but (embarrassingly) in the fat on the back of my arm and the girl gave it slooowwwlly.  It only burned very slightly at one point, but I can see if they gave it fast where it would hurt like the dickens.  I've heard of a number of folks who've gotten the shot in the stomach, too. Moe:  Would Aloe Vera gel help the itching?  Are you conditioning your scalp with conditioner like you would if you had a full head of hair?  I've wondered how to care for my scalp once the hair is gone and wondered if I should treat it like I would normally -- good shampoo and conditioner.  Just didn't know if that would do any good. AmyK:  I've heard that the ginger can really make a difference.  I've tried the tea, too, but not during the tx itself.  I've also found some ginger "candy" at my health food store and that also did a nice job of settling my stomach when I was out riding in the car with my husband.  You're right, though, it is really "peppery."  Don't know that I could have more than one piece in quick succession. Good luck to anyone who might be starting tx tomorrow.  I don't have anyone on my list, specifically, but for anyone lurking or who wasn't sure when they would start originally, hope everything goes well for you!

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 05:02AM JulieH wrote: IslandMom:  Wow!  $200 for a Brazilian?  I knew there was a reason I'd never gone to get one (well, that and being overly modest . . .)  UTMom:  I love the new style.  I think it looks great from the picture.  Sounds like a lot of you are finding wigs you're really pleased with. ProudMom:  I agree with enjoying the ease of hair care in the morning.  I had a friend recommend coconut oil for my scalp when the hair is gone.  She said it's a good way to avoid the "scalys" if it dries out.  I'm wondering if it wouldn't be too greasy.  But it's worth a try -- that and some good sunscreen. Lorenar:  The fatigue is definitely one of the worst SEs.  But good for you for being able to stay on top of the household things.  I'm afraid I've let that slip, but then, I've never been much of a housekeeper.  And you're right, sometimes we have to laugh at this lamentable situation we find ourselves in. I try to maintain my sense of humor when possible.  There's a great thread on this site "you know you're a cancer patient when" where the ladies try to find the humor in the situation.  I've really enjoyed reading through it, and gotten some real laughs. Annie:  Glad your SEs started off easier -- here's to hoping that continues! Baf4292:  You too -- have you been doing anything different to combat the SEs?  Hope you continue to be comfortable.  All you in the middle and NE of the country -- stay safe and warm and be careful when you have to be out.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 08:31PM JulieH wrote: yorelh:  I have pretty much sailed through radiation.  My breast is red and tender (I did not have a mx), but I haven't had any major skin problems. Also, I'm 5 months out from my surgery, so my incisions (node and breast) had a long time to heal. You might want to read through the May rads forum.  A number of the ladies went through the subclavicle regimen and you might be able to get some insight.  My guess is they wouldn't mind you pm-ing them to ask.  I think a lot of it depends on the intensity your RO prescribes for you.  On the whole breast radiation, I had 5 zaps from the top at about the 2 o'clock position and 5 from about the 7 o'clock position.  The first zap was 10 seconds and the next four were 1 second each.  From what I gather, some women have longer zaps, which likely contributes to how severe a reaction you get.  I have had some minor fatigue, but nothing that (except for a couple of days) MADE me take a nap. Chemo was harder for me. I got the radiology report on my ultrasound and there doesn't seem to be a clot, so that was good news.  Still don't know why my arm is hurting, but it seems to be getting a little less painful so my onc said we'd just watch it for the time being and see if it continues to get better.   Thanks for all your well-wishes.  It was nice for something to come out good for a change.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2012 07:15PM JulieH wrote: So good to hear from you again, Mary Meg.  I often wonder what has happened with those we made the journey with, and I'm glad to hear you're doing well and enjoying life. I have to say, I'm very envious of your travels.  Have you been to Beijing, or is that in the future?  Be safe and have fun! I definitely feel the chemo fog.  I have more trouble concentrating and focusing on a thought, and I get frustrated and flustered so much more easily.  Money and balancing accounts really give me trouble.  I also had the AC/TH, but no carboplatin, so I imagine if I'm having issues, it's likely you definitely are. In the meantime, I and my DH keep plugging along, spending too much time at the oncologist's office, going to appointments.  Don't know what they'd do if we weren't spending our money there.    The nurses at the radiation oncology center looked at me and said, "I know you," and I said "yes, you do."  Thankfully, DH's radiation will only be 14 treatments and at a level about half the intensity I received.  Hopefully that will knock it out.  The joy of lymphoma is that it will almost always, inevitably, come back. Take care! Julie

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 01:01PM - edited Dec 28, 2010 01:06PM by JulieH 99Sporty:  Welcome -- sorry you're here.  Good luck with the port placement tomorrow and your first tx Thursday.  You may have seen the thread with tips for getting through chemo, but if you havent, the click here for the link.  There is some really useful information.  You might also visit the REALLY active December 2010 thread too.  I have lurked over there for the last few weeks and followed those ladies (and one husband) as they've begun their tx -- they've got great tips, too, and I've found what they have to say very informative. baf4292: Welcome to you, too!  Wish you weren't here, either!  I know what you mean about the suspense -- the waiting is the worst, and it seems that waiting is so much of what we do when we're first diagnosed.  Hope you find out soon, to ease your mind a little.  At least you know what regimen you'll be following -- it's so much easier to educate yourself about what to expect when you know what drugs you'll be getting.  I'm going to try to keep working, too, although I realize that some days it might just not be possible -- thankfully my principal is very supportive.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 05:00PM JulieH wrote: Tammy:  I decided when I first found out I'd be getting the chemo that I didn't want to do a wig -- I think I'll feel better with the hats and scarves.  I know it will probably elicit a lot of questions from the kids I work with, and, knowing middle-schoolers, a lot of "looks," but I just don't think I'd feel comfortable with a wig.  That said, I used to work in elementary schools, and it might be harder for the little ones to see us without hair. In the end, I think each of us needs to decide what will make us, personally, the most comfortable.  I think I'd have had a harder time with the surgery, and really admire the strength it must take to deal with that.   I am trying to figure out how to tell the kids what I'm going through.  When I was out for my lumpectomy the first time, they were very curious about where I'd been, and I just said I'd had to have surgery.  Now I'm going to be out next week after my re-excision, and there's no way I'm going to be able to hide the hair loss and the other effects the tx are going to have, so I need to find a way to answer their questions that isn't too complicated or scary (although I'm amazed sometimes what young teens can handle).  I know that's a few weeks in the future, but I'm the kind who likes to plan ahead.  My surgery and port placement is tomorrow.  I really don't like surgery . . .

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 11:59AM JulieH wrote: Good thoughts and best wishes islandmom, proud_mom, and AliT as you prepare for your first tx tomorrow.  You will be very much on our minds.  I hope everything goes smoothly and relatively SE free. {{{{{{HUGS}}}}}} I'm going back to work tomorrow -- wasn't originally planning to, but I feel well enough to go ahead.  I have Dr. appts on Thurs (onc.+ chemo teach) and Fri (post-op check up), so I'll only be at work half a day.  Guess I'm a little scared about the follow-up to my re-excision.  Seems I keep getting the worst news possible under the circumstances (first DCIS dx, then the lumpectomy showed it's a much larger area and IDC to boot), and I'm afraid they're going to tell me they found more C in the ducts and the lumpectomy isn't sufficient.  I know a lot of you have had the mx and it's possible to get through it -- I'm just kind of surgeried out, you know? Anyhow -- good luck to our new starters.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 06:52AM JulieH wrote: I've missed so much since I've been away from the board.  I'm so happy for all of you finishing up -- big congratulations to you!  It must be such a relief.  I know I'm glad to be done with the AC, especially as the SEs have been almost constant and now I seem to have developed hand-foot syndrome in my hands -- no blisters but I have the red scaly skin and bad itching/tingling.  From what I read, I think it will go away now that the Adriamycin is done.  I'll have my first Taxol/Herceptin this coming Tuesday (they tell me about 6 hours for the first time in the chair) and am really, really, really hoping that nausea isn't an issue with it.  I have so lost my taste for food -- anyone else have that, too?  Honestly, I was happy to be 1/2 way done last week, but now I realize I have 1/2 way to go and then a whole year of Herceptin.  I think I'm just done mentally with this whole thing and wish it would just END. Good luck, everyone, in the coming week with your journeys -- may it be easy for you!

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 03:09PM JulieH wrote: Welcome queenjazz and slcst12! I went back to school today and by noon was having a lot of pain in my breast where I had the lumpectomy. Came home and crashed, but feel like such a baby. Too, my assistant is just getting over a raging flu and is not very careful about where she breathes and how she coughs (we both work at the circulation computer) and the last thing I want going into this is to come down with something, even though I've had the flu vaccine. Can we be too careful about sickness? I've got a list of questions for my onco when I see him tomorrow: do I need bone scans/heart function tests? Will I be getting Emend (I know it's expensive, but it sounds like a wonder drug for nausea)? What about Claritin/Glutamine? Thanks to everyone for sharing your experiences -- it's really helping me to know what to ask. Queenjazz: Hope your tx went well today. Let us know how you're doing. slcst12: Looks like we'll be twins (at least for the first few rounds) on this journey -- unfortunately for both of us! With the FDA's recent ruling, will the Avastin still be available? For your wig, definitely check with your local Am. Cancer Society chapter. Also related to the ACS, tlcdirect.org is another place I've read about. Anyone else have some resources? islandmom: Glad you've found a regimen you're more comfortable with. Sorry it means travelling a little further, but to be comfortable is going to be SO important as you start the journey. I know I'm scared about the Adriamycin, but given the size of my tumor and the extensive ductal component and the HER2 positive status of my BC, I want to go at this with the big guns now so I never have to do it again. Good luck tomorrow! bamamama: Hope your haircut was a succes -- I felt really strange after mine, and the kids at school today were doing a lot of double-takes when they saw me, but I really like it, now. Hope it wasn't bad for you! proudmom: Good for you! I hope when you read this that your side effects continue to be minimal. I am in awe of those of you who are going to give yourselves the neulasta/neupogen shots. There is no way I could do that. Hope the shot is easy for you tomorrow. Are you taking Claritin for the neulasta pain? Good luck to you ladies starting tomorrow: islandmom, navywife, and MaryMeg. We'll be thinking of you. {{{{{HUGS}}}}} all around.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 10:07AM JulieH wrote: Melissa:  I was just thinking of you yesterday and wondering how you were doing.  Congrats on finishing the Taxol!  I'm pretty wiped out today from my first round.  Hope it goes away soon -- guess it's all cumulative. I won't sugar coat it -- I had a rough time with the AC.  The first round wasn't too bad; I took four days off from work plus the weekend and went back on Monday and was OK.  Each tx, though, the nausea and fatigue lasted longer.  I was able to go back to work each week on Monday, but just felt worse longer.  The last round of AC really wiped me out -- I just wasn't really able to function for about 5 days and made myself go to work the next week.  Hemorrhoids and constipation were always a problem, colace seemed to help, but a laxative would probably have been a good idea, too.  I would get mouth sores about a week out from the tx and I had dry eyes that were really helped with Gen-Teal eye gel each night.  Finally with the last AC I developed hand/foot syndrome (red palms, swelling, scaly skin in the creases of the palms and fingers, and bad pain and itching), which apparently really needs looking at if it happens early in the txs.  I've also completely lost my taste for food -- nothing sounds good and I really have to force myself to eat and drink anything.  I was hoping this wouldn't be an issue with the Taxol, but it seems to be back with a vengeance today. Anyhow -- I know it's not a pretty picture, and it may not be as tough for you.  I hope not.  Best of luck, and check in when you can.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 06:12PM JulieH wrote: Had my MUGA scan today -- it went smoothly and wasn't any problem.  Made better by the fact that the tech who started the IV line to draw the blood was maybe the best I've ever had -- barely felt anything.  Sherry:  I, too, am having major leg pain plus abdominal/lower back pain from my first taxol tx.  I just cannot get comfortable -- I'm going to need to take something to help me sleep tonight.  I have the glutamine here and think I'll start in on that.  I just hate adding another med to the mix.  The saving grace is that I haven't taken any anti-nauseals other than the Emend that I finished yesterday, so I guess I'm even. slcst:  The pain in my fingertips has been replaced by numbness.  Don't know if that's clinically better, but at least I can open things without pain . . .  Hope your pain subsides, too. Christine:  I, too, wish I could just go to sleep and wake up on the other side of this mess.  Does the vicodin really help with the pain?  I have some left over from my surgeries and was contemplating that tonight (the more I write, the less even I am with my meds ).  Good luck with the SEs, everyone.  Have a pleasant weekend!

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 03:32PM JulieH wrote: Welcome Enigma & Starella! Enigma: Have you taken anything specific for the heartburn? I've seen on other boards both Pepcid and/or Prevacid and was wondering how either/each of those work on the chemo heartburn. Are you doing the Taxol every week? Glad things are going well for the most part! Hi citykitty! Good to hear from you. Lucky you the steroids didn't jazz you up too much. That's a SE I'm not looking forward to -- I have enough trouble sleeping as it is without exacerbating it with drugs. But, oh well, I know it's necessary. At least I won't have major steroids until I start the T/H. Hope the pain isn't too bad for you. AimeeMac: So, so sorry the SEs were so bad. Hope it eases up soon for you. Nutella is one of my favorite things, and, you know, they advertise it as being healthy for you! :-) queenjazz - Yay for minimal SEs! My neck was really sore from the port for several days. And it still feels like it "pinches" sometimes, but that's getting better, too. Hope yours feels better soon! Starella: Hope the mouth sore clears up soon for you. Good question about how often to rinse. I'm not sure about the benadryl/maalox mix, but the instructions from my chemo nurse about the baking soda/salt mixture say to swish after meals and at bedtime. Looks like Aimster1123 (AmyK) and tsundermann (Tammy) are due to start their tx tomorrow. Here's wishing you ladies the best. {{{{{HUGS}}}}} everyone!

"When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive - to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love." - Marcus Aurelius Chemo started 1/18/11. Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 06:32PM - edited Jan 13, 2011 06:33PM by JulieH Hey all!  Having kind of a bad day today.  Wasn't too bad, but I had to come face to face with this crappy disease again this evening, and I don't much like it.  I've been the captain of my school's Relay for Life team for the last few years and was on the organizing committee last year and was hoping to be again this year and was really hoping to be able to keep up my level of activity.  Well, we had a captain's meeting today and I saw that the chemo nurse who did my teach last week is one of the captains for my cancer center's team so we were talking aftewards.  She said she was surprised to see my name on some of the things.  So I asked her "honest opinion" if she thought I would be up to doing what I've done in the past.  She hesitated so I said "honest opinion" again and she hesitated then said "you're going to be really tired."  Which I know isn't saying I definitely won't be up to it, but I know at some point I'm going to have to accept that I'll need to slow down.  I have a hard time with that . . .  I hate this whole process. Anyhow, I do want to wish our tomorrow starters, WebU and Vis0121, a smooth treatment, minimal side effects, and a good day.  We'll be thinking of you! Sleep well tonight (or good morning for those of you waking up to read these posts).

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 03:25PM JulieH wrote: aimster: So sorry the nausea kicked in so bad. It must be a relief that there is that pump available for you. Are you only doing the TC or Adriamycin also? The cytoxan seems to be notorious for the nausea. Glad the Marinol at least keeps things at bay. My doc is giving me the Neulasta as a matter of course because I'm doing the dose dense AC. Seems like what they do routinely at my center. 99sporty: Yay for the lump shrinking! That has got to be such a great feeling -- and confirmation that as hard as it can be, the chemo is doing what it's supposed to. My DH and I felt that way when the chemo he was on shrank his major tumor from softball to less than a quarter it's original size. islandmom: Glad you're feeling so good -- I'm pulling for it to continue for you. Good luck with the exercise. vis0121: So sorry it hasn't gotten any better. I do hope your onc is open to trying something for you. There are so many different things out there to help control the nausea, and you've got to be able to get some fluids in you. Hang in there! We're all thinking of you! MaryMeg: You are so on top of things and really an inspiration. I don't think I could do classes that early in the morning (I am really NOT a morning person), but I'd sure like to be able to be more serious about the exercise. I don't think it sounds at all like you're paranoid, but, rather, just serious about kicking this thing to the curb. slcst12 and Betsey: Good luck to you both at your first tx tomorrow. I'll be thinking of you as I sit in the infusion chair. Take care everyone!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 07:41PM JulieH wrote: Lots of activity today. Congrats in advance, Tammy!  I am t minus 6 days and counting.  If the pattern holds, I won't feel much like imbibing until about 8 days after that, but you can bet I am looking forward to some margaritas, too.  I'm not a big drinker, but I like some good wine with a special meal and the occasional potent margarita at a local Mexican restaurant.  Have a great time at your party! You know you're a cancer patient when you actually look forward to shaving.  I have hair on my arms and have had to shave my legs maybe three times in the last four months.  Most of my eyelashes and nose hair is gone and my eyebrows are straggly, at best.  Wearing glasses has helped to hide that, I think, although it hasn't been as hard mentally as I thought it would be for me.  I find it odd that my finger and toenails have continued to grow normally while my hair hasn't.  I would have thought they'd be affected, too. I'm envious of all of you who can take Ambien -- I tried it once a couple of years ago and it made me do and see crazy things (hallucinations, sleep walking, etc.).  I take temazepam on my treatment weeks, but it only keeps me asleep about 6 hours, then I wake up and my mind starts racing.  Non-treatment weeks I seem to be able to get back in my old routine, just in time to start all over again.  But there's just one more week of that!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 06:05AM JulieH wrote: Day 2 after AC and I'm still feeling pretty good. Neulasta today in just a couple of hours. Then I can stay away from the cancer center for a couple of weeks (barring anything bad happening). Yayy! SusanLynn: Sounds like you had a lovely day. Did you take your own pedi instruments? I'm always getting nicked when I get my pedis and I'm desperately afraid now to get one done in case they cut me again. Just sorry your salmon salad didn't turn out as planned. queenjazz: good to know the dry mouth isn't unusual so quickly. I drank so much yesterday I spent more time in the bathroom yesterday than I normally do in three days combined. My DH thinks I'm way underhydrated normally . . . Good luck with your tx today -- here hoping for continued minimal SEs! slcst12: How are you doing today? Were you able to rest at all yesterday? If the nausea continues, be sure to call the onc's office; there's got to be something more they can do -- I sure hope so, anyway. Take care and do let us know how you're feeling as soon as you're up to it. Tammy: Good to know that a few days out you're doing so well. I'm hoping to be going back to school on day 7, so you're giving me some hope. It is empowering, isn't it, to know that we're finally on our way to kicking this thing. And it's great that you have such a great support system! aimster1123: I'm sure pulling for you to be able to get yourself off the pump soon. It's difficult to say which is worse, isn't it? Diarrhea or constipation . . . Sure would be nice to have some in-between, wouldn't it? Beckie: Good luck with yor port placement today. It may be sore for a few days, but it has gotten much better for me. I finally noticed last night that it wasn't pinching at all as I went to sleep. And best of luck on your first TC on Friday -- I'm sure you can do it (may not always be easy, but maybe you'll be able to sail through). Here's hoping for the absolute best. It sounds like you have your arsenal in hand! Betsey: Did they give you the benedryl with your premeds? That will definitely make you foggy. So glad your SEs were as small as they were. Are your tx every three weeks? I couldn't remember. But, most of all, Happy Birthday! AimeeMac: I actually really like the purple in your hair -- sorry it's coming out, but, hey, you can always redo it when your hair comes back. I know a lot of ladies get tired of the pink we get to see so often for BC, but my hairdresser said she puts a pink streak in her hair for October BC awareness month. Made me hope I'd have enough hair back by then to put some pink in mine. Good luck with yours in the next couple of days. Aimster: I know what you mean about worrying about bald spots. With my hair as short as it is right now, I've been wondering if when it comes out I could have big gaps in the back that I wouldn't see. I'd rather take it all of than have that and look like my cat did when he had ringworm. I start pulling hunks out, and I'm going to shave the whole shebang. Love to see a pic of your new do when/if you're feeling up to it. Jane_UK: Good luck on your tx tomorrow. We're pulling for you!

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 01:27PM JulieH wrote: Did my final taxol today!  I know I can get through a few days of physical pain as it is the last time I'll have to do this (staying positive here!).  Talked with the onc and he said, after much consideration, that he really doesn't think Tomixifen would help me much as I'm only 1% ER+.  For me, this is really good news since I really didn't want to face five years of another drug.  I asked and he did say that a hysterectomy/oopherectomy would probably be a good idea in my case, so I'll probably be calling my GYN in the next couple of weeks.  I think I could have that surgery (yayy!!! more surgery!!!) after our vacation and still be up and running for the beginning of school in August.  We talked and he said that while it is highly likely that the chemo has thrown me into permanent menopause s(I woke up last night drenched . . .) he has seen cases where, in his words, the ovaries have come "clawing back to life" 6 months or more down the line, so the oopherectomy would forestall that happening.  I, too, am planning to take off some of my body fat this summer, like you mentionned, bdavis.  I'm actually looking forward to starting some exercise.  He said I'd want to schedule my next mammogram 6 months from the end of chemo -- guess that's six months from today.  While the Herceptin tx are an annoyance, they're a cake walk compared to everything else.  Carla:  Good to hear from you and hear how relatively well you're doing.  Hope the recovery process is quick and easy for you!

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2011 07:55AM JulieH wrote: Happy 4th! UTMom:  My energy is mainly back, but my body is not so much so.  I am finding my joints, especially in my legs and ankles, remain creaky and achy.  I asked my onc about it, and he said there's a good chance it may stay this way.  So now I feel 70, rather than 30 (I'm actually 45), when I try to get around.  I keep telling myself that the alternative would be worse, and I know it's so, but I can't help mourning the loss of my body as I knew it in this process. That's the first time I heard of a doctor wanting to keep the port in "just in case."  I think I'd be a little freaked out if it had been me.  I know I've got to keep mine for a year for the Herceptin, but I'm going to want it out at the end of the school year next year. I, too, have a D cup and have been on my back for rads.  I suspect it has a lot to do with the placement of where the tumor was. My skin has held up very well.  I am not peeling at all and look mostly like I have a bad burn.  Of course, as I understand it, the intensity of the radiation depends on the extent and severity of the cancer at the beginning.  I was lucky to have caught mine before any spread and so my course of rads may be less intense than others who were not so lucky. Also, I have followed my RO's instructions to the letter.  Aquaphor once a day starting about one week in but just enough to rub in lightly -- never heavy.  Then, a week later, twice a day, right after rads and then right before bed, using the same light amount.  My RO said if it hadn't been absorbed in the skin by the time I got up in the morning, I was using too much.  I have only two more boosts (tomorrow and Wed.) and then I'm done.  My energy is much better now than when I was on chemo.  I have had a couple of days when I just had to take a nap, but otherwise have been able to function just fine.  I've also begun to walk in the evenings with my husband and have started gentle exercise classes at the "Y" and haven't had any problems. I still have the pain in my arm, but it seems to be a little better.  I actually went to a gentle yoga class this week and thought it felt better after.  Seems a little counterintuitive to me, but nevertheless . . . Hope y'all are having a good day today.  My DH and I are off to the quintessentially American activity this evening -- a baseball game (the local A baseball team) and fireworks afterwards.  The crowds are usually horrible, but we always have a good time.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 03:25PM JulieH wrote:  Could be an infection.  But, if mammogram doesn't find anything and/or antibiotics don't clear it up, don't give up on trying to find a diagnosis.  The information below is from WebMD and concerns inflammatory breast cancer (IBC).  If things persist, ask for a referral to a breast specialist.  From WebMD:  What Are the Symptoms of Inflammatory Breast Cancer? Unlike the more common form of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer does not generally show up as a lump. The disease grows as nests or sheets that clog the lymph system under the skin. Often the symptoms are attributed to other diseases and thus the diagnosis may take a long time to occur. Symptoms of inflammatory breast cancer include: These changes often occur quickly, over a period of weeks. How Is Inflammatory Breast Cancer Diagnosed? Inflammatory breast cancer is often misdiagnosed as another medical condition. It's important to pursue a breast or skin biopsy if treatments for another breast condition like an infection don't work.
Posts.Title: help..symptoms getting worse ILTMB ILTMB

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 05:49PM JulieH wrote: Just to let you know that you don't always get completely accurate info about your dx with a needle biopsy.  I had my ultrasound needle guided biopsy done in November and the path report showed only DCIS in an area of almost 2cm and was shown to be ER (estrogen receptor) and PR (progesterone receptor) negative..  Based on that and an MRI that my surgeon ordered to see if there were any other areas of cancer in either of my breasts (MRI showed no other activity), I opted for a lumpectomy and was planning for radiation.  The lumpectomy was done on 12/1/10 and when I went in a week and a half later for the path report, the surgeon told me that, in fact, the mass was a mix of DCIS and IDC (invasice ductal carcinoma).  The IDC component was 1.7 cm and the total mass was almost 3cm (I guess I should change that in my signature . . .). At the time of the lumpectomy I also had a sentinel node biopsy which was negative. The IDC was ER+/PR-.   So, the lumpectomy provided the definitive information, which in major areas was different from the needle biopsy information. Because the clear area around the tissue taken in the original surgery, was small (1 mm) I am opting for re-excision to clean out the area around where the tumor was located (to be sure the margins are clear) to be followed by chemo and radiation after that.  My whole medical team agrees that the lumpectomy route is as good a choice for me as mastectomy (mx) would be.  For me, this was the preferable choice because I know they have made so many positive strides in cure rates for BC, and because keeping my breast was important to me.  There is no history of BC (or any cancer other than sun-related melanoma) in my family, so that was another factor. But, I would highly recommend getting a complete pathology picture through lumpectomy/node biopsy first, as you can always go back and get the full mx if that will ease your mind about future worries -- a completely valid reason to do the mx. Also, a couple of sites with good, clear information on BC are: Susan G. Komen site, the DCIS site from the Cancer Prevention Institute of California, the information on the path report here at breastcancer.org, as well as the informtion on treatment options and decisions on this site.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 06:14PM JulieH wrote: With my lumpectomy, they did not do anything to "fill in" the area -- I don't think that's usually done.  It's my understanding that fatty tissue will eventually fill it in to an extent.  The difference in size is not too great, frankly, but that may be because I have a D cup and the area taken was relatively small.  If your tumor is big relative to your breast size, you may not have as good a result -- your surgeon should be able to tell you whether he/she thinks the cosmetic result will be good. The clear margins are determined when they send the tissue sample out to the pathologist, so, no, they can't tell in the operating room -- I wish they could have, it would have saved me the extra surgery, but re-excision seems to be fairly common (my re-excision is sched. for this Thursday).  That said, because my mass was larger than they were expecting, that may have led to the small clear margins in my case.

I'm wondering about the underwire bra thing.  Is there a reason other than skin sensitivity why we're told not to wear an underwire bra?  I really don't like not being "supported" and have always disliked bras without an underwire.  I'd much rather wear an underwire bra -- just one thing that I could do to be more comfortable mentally during this whole thing. Time to go put my numbing cream on my port.  Hope everyone has a great day!

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 11:46AM JulieH wrote: Proud_Mom:  from the Livestrong.com website: "Healthy, well-balanced diets ensure that you're getting the proper vitamins and nutrients for your immune system. Fruits, vegetables, whole grains and fish are all rich in vitamins, antioxidants and minerals, so make sure to get at least your daily allowance of each. Oranges, grapefruits, strawberries, nuts, spinach (and other green, leafy vegetables), avocado, tomatoes, carrots, apricots and cold-water fish are some of the most beneficial to your immune system." and "Increase your intake of zinc. While a well-balanced diet can go a long way toward boosting the health of your white blood cells, zinc actually stimulates their production. Try to get anywhere between 15 and 25 mg each day. Many cereals are fortified with this mineral, but you can also find it naturally in beef, legumes, turkey and crab." Plus exercise and rest. Read more: http://www.livestrong.com/article/29611-boost-white-blood-cell-count/#ixzz1OK3payRN I know, I was surprised when my MO said that rads could lower our counts.  I thought I was out of the woods after my last chemo and Neulasta shot.  Guess not entirely . . .

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2011 11:30PM JulieH wrote: I was told not to lose weight for the simple reason that it would change my breast too much and they would need to re-scan me and re-do the plan for the rads.  I have a good 25 pounds that I need to take off, but I'm holding off getting serious about that until July 6th.  My treatment consists of 4 zaps in each of two positions of the machine -- both through the breast from above at about the 2 o'clock position and then below from about the 8 o'clock position.  The first zap in each position is about 10 seconds and then the next three zaps in each position are only 1 second each.  Tomorrow I'll be half way through.  I have some pinkness and tenderness, but so far so good.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 01:09PM JulieH wrote: I, too, will be starting rads in May, on the 19th.  I have my last taxol tx this coming Tuesday (have done 4 months of DD A/C then T.  I really like my rad. onc, she's got a great personality and really takes the time to talk and answer questions.  She said that while the radiation usually is fatiguing, it's nothing compared to the fatigue that comes with chemo.  My RO's office uses/recommends  for a lotion.  I'm not wild about heavy, greasy creams, but I guess if it cuts down the skin effects, I can deal with it.  They did tell me no anti-perspirant for the duration of treatment -- not something I'm looking forward to living in SC's hot, humid summers.  Does anyone know off-hand if baby powder is also off limits?  I won't have tattoos, just the markings that they'll reapply over the course of tx.  Glad to join the group.
